choices.text: Works as a vaginal pH regulator
Contains lactic acid, citric acid, and potassium bitartrate
Creates an acidic vaginal environment inhospitable for sperms

questions.text: Phexxi, a newly approved contraceptive gel, has the following properties except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Provides long-term hormonal contraception

 

Phexxi is a non-hormonal contraceptive vaginal gel approved by the FDA. It acts locally within the vagina to maintain an acidic pH (around 3.5–4.5), which is unfavorable for sperm motility and function. Its effect is temporary and used immediately before intercourse, not long-term.

 

Mechanism of Action:

 

  • Phexxi contains lactic acid, citric acid, and potassium bitartrate, which help maintain vaginal acidity even in the presence of semen (which is alkaline).
  • This acidic environment immobilizes sperms, preventing fertilization.

choices.text: Total abdominal hysterectomy + BSO without lymph node dissection
Total abdominal hysterectomy + BSO + lymph node dissection
Total abdominal hysterectomy + BSO + lymph node dissection + Adjuvant RT
Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy with Cisplatin and Paclitaxel

questions.text: A 52-year-old postmenopausal woman is diagnosed with endometrial cancer, FIGO stage IA, tumor size 1.5 cm, grade 2 adenocarcinoma. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Total abdominal hysterectomy + BSO without lymph node dissection

 

In early-stage endometrial carcinoma (FIGO Stage IA, Grade 1–2, <50% myometrial invasion), the standard management is surgical removal of the uterus with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (TAH + BSO) without the need for lymph node dissection or adjuvant radiotherapy.

 

Lymph node dissection is generally reserved for higher-grade (G3) tumors or when >50% myometrial invasion is suspected (Stage IB or higher).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Total abdominal hysterectomy + BSO + lymph node dissection: Incorrect.

 

  • Lymph node dissection is done in Grade 3 or deeply invasive tumors (≥50% myometrial invasion).
  • In this case, both grade and invasion are low, so unnecessary.

 

Option C. Total abdominal hysterectomy + BSO + lymph node dissection + Adjuvant RT: Incorrect.
 

  • Adjuvant radiotherapy is indicated only for high-intermediate risk or advanced disease (Stage IB G3 or higher).
  • Not recommended in early, low-grade cases due to overtreatment risk.

 

Option D. Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy with Cisplatin and Paclitaxel: Incorrect.
 

  • Chemotherapy is used for advanced or metastatic disease, not in early-stage IA tumors.

 

Summary Table:

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman has a right-sided ovarian mass found incidentally on transvaginal ultrasound. Surgery is planned to remove the right ovary, including the mass. To avoid excessive bleeding during the oophorectomy, the surgeon should ligate which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Suspensory ligament of the ovary 

 

The suspensory ligament of the ovary (infundibulopelvic ligament) contains the ovarian vessels (ovarian artery and vein), lymphatics, and nerves.
During oophorectomy (removal of the ovary), this ligament must be ligated to prevent excessive bleeding from these vessels.

 

  • The ovarian artery arises directly from the abdominal aorta (at L2 level).
  • The ovarian vein drains into the IVC (right) or left renal vein (left).
    Hence, controlling this vascular pedicle is essential before the ovary is excised.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mesosalpinx: Incorrect.
 

  • This is the portion of the broad ligament that encloses the fallopian tube.
  • It contains small branches of the uterine and ovarian arteries supplying the tube, not the main ovarian vessels.
  • Ligation here is done during salpingectomy, not oophorectomy.

 

Option B. Ovarian ligament: Incorrect.

 

  • This connects the ovary to the lateral wall of the uterus (near uterine cornu).
  • It contains utero-ovarian anastomosis. 

 

Option C. Round ligament of the uterus: Incorrect.
 

  • This runs from the uterine cornu through the inguinal canal to the labia majora.
  • It maintains the anteverted position of the uterus, contains the Sampson’s artery, branch of inferior epigastric artery.

choices.text: Streak gonads and male internal genitalia
Streak gonads and female internal genitalia
Empty pelvis (no gonads or internal genitalia)
Bilateral abdominal testes and male internal genitalia

questions.text: A 26-year-old nulligravida presents with primary amenorrhea. She is diagnosed with 46XY gonadal dysgenesis. During pelvic laparoscopy, what is the expected finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Streak gonads and female internal genitalia

 

In 46,XY gonadal dysgenesis (Swyer syndrome), there is a mutation or deletion of the SRY gene (on the Y chromosome) that normally initiates testis differentiation.


Because the SRY gene is nonfunctional, the primitive gonads fail to develop into testes, and instead form streak gonads (fibrous tissue).

 

  • Since no functional testes develop, anti-Müllerian hormone (AMH) and testosterone are both absent.
  • Therefore, the Müllerian ducts persist, leading to female internal genitalia (uterus, fallopian tubes, upper vagina).
  • The external genitalia also develop as female due to the absence of androgens.

 

Thus, on laparoscopy, we find:

 

  • Streak gonads (fibrous, non-functional structures)
  • Normal/hypoplastic female internal genitalia (uterus, tubes, vagina)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streak gonads and male internal genitalia: Incorrect.

 

  • Male internal genitalia (epididymis, vas deferens, seminal vesicles) develop only under testosterone influence.
  • In this syndrome, testes (and hence testosterone) are absent, so male ducts don’t form.

 

Option C. Empty pelvis (no gonads or internal genitalia): Incorrect.

 

  • Seen in Müllerian agenesis (MRKH syndrome): 46,XX karyotype, normal ovaries, but absent uterus and upper vagina.
  • In Swyer syndrome, uterus is present.

 

Option D. Bilateral abdominal testes and male internal genitalia: Incorrect.

 

  • Seen in Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS) — testes present (often intra-abdominal), but due to androgen receptor defect, external genitalia are female and internal male ducts are absent due to AMH.
  • Not seen in gonadal dysgenesis.

choices.text: Hyperflexion of spine may be seen
Spontaneous expulsion rarely occurs in these patients and induction is required
Infection by gas-forming organisms is likely after rupture of membranes

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida at 32 weeks of gestation comes with complaints of absent fetal movements over the last week. Examination shows absent fetal heart sounds. Ultrasonographic examination shows overlapping of skull bones and absent FHR. Which of the following is false about this likely condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Spontaneous expulsion rarely occurs in these patients and induction is required

 

The clinical picture indicates intrauterine fetal demise (IUFD) — also known as a missed intrauterine death.


Ultrasound findings like overlapping of skull bones (Spalding sign), absence of fetal cardiac activity, and possibly Robert’s sign (gas in great vessels or heart) confirm fetal death.

 

In most cases, spontaneous expulsion of the dead fetus occurs within 2 weeks due to uterine irritability and prostaglandin release. Hence, the statement that “spontaneous expulsion rarely occurs and induction is required” is false.

 

  • Spontaneous expulsion commonly occurs within 2 weeks; if not, induction is then undertaken to prevent DIC and infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Robert’s sign may be seen: Correct. Refers to gas shadow in the heart or great vessels seen on X-ray or ultrasound after fetal death. Appears usually within 12–24 hours of demise.

 

Option B. Hyperflexion of spine may be seen: Correct. Due to loss of muscle tone and maceration, fetal spine often shows abnormal postures like hyperflexion.

 

Option D. Infection by gas-forming organisms is likely after rupture of membranes: Correct. Once membranes rupture, the retained dead fetus predisposes to infection with Clostridium and other gas-forming bacteria.

 

Summary Table:

questions.text: What is the best time to perform the following procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 11-13 weeks

 

The image shows Chorionic Villus Sampling (CVS) — a prenatal diagnostic procedure in which a sample of chorionic villi from the placenta is aspirated under ultrasound guidance.


It is used for early genetic diagnosis of chromosomal or metabolic abnormalities (e.g., Down syndrome, thalassemia, Tay-Sachs).

 

  • Best timing: 11–13 weeks of gestation (ideally around 11 weeks).
  • Performing CVS before 10 weeks increases the risk of limb reduction defects and oromandibular hypogenesis.

questions.solution:
Ans. C) First Pelvic grip

 

The image shows the Third Leopold’s Maneuver (also called the First Pelvic Grip or Pawlik grip).

choices.text: Granulosa cell tumor
Embryonal cell tumor

questions.text: Identify the incorrect pair:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Embryonal cell tumor

 

 

Image 1 → Dysgerminoma:

 

  • Microscopy: Sheets of uniform round cells with clear cytoplasm, central nuclei (“fried-egg appearance”), fibrous septa infiltrated by lymphocytes.
  • Analogous to: Seminoma of testis.
  • Marker: ↑ LDH, PLAP.
     Diagnosis: Dysgerminoma.

 

Image 2 → Granulosa cell tumor:

 

  • Microscopy: Superfical cells seen on Pap smear indicating Estrogen production by GCT. 

 

Image 3 → Teratoma:

 

  • Microscopy: Contains mature elements from multiple germ layers—skin, hair follicles, sebaceous glands, etc.
  • Grossly: May show “dermoid cyst” with hair and teeth.Diagnosis: Mature cystic teratoma.

 

Image 4 → (Incorrectly labeled as Embryonal cell tumor):

 

It actually shows biphasic trophoblastic proliferation — cytotrophoblasts (clear cells) and syncytiotrophoblasts (multinucleated, eosinophilic cells) surrounding hemorrhage and necrosis.

 

This is characteristic of Choriocarcinoma — a malignant germ cell tumor of trophoblastic origin, not embryonal cell tumor.

 

Note: Embryonal cell carcinoma histology shows primitive, anaplastic cells arranged in various architectural patterns like solid sheets, tubular/glandular structures, or papillary formations. Key features include large, pleomorphic cells with abundant cytoplasm, prominent nucleoli, and a high rate of mitotic activity.

questions.text: A P1L1 mother with BMI of 35 diagnosed with pre-eclampsia underwent LSCS. What is the ideal agent for prophylaxis post-partum venous thromboembolism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) LMWH

 

Women who are postpartum, especially after cesarean section and with additional risk factors like obesity (BMI >30) and preeclampsia, are at high risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE).


In such high-risk patients, pharmacologic prophylaxis is required in addition to mechanical measures.

 

The agent of choice for postpartum VTE prophylaxis is Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH), started 6–12 hours after cesarean delivery (once hemostasis is assured).

 

LMWH is preferred because:

 

  • Predictable anticoagulant effect
  • No need for routine monitoring
  • Safe in breastfeeding
  • Lower risk of HIT (heparin-induced thrombocytopenia) compared to unfractionated heparin

 

Note: Given for at least 7 days, or longer if risk persists

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Warfarin: Incorrect.

 

  • Not used for initial postpartum prophylaxis; it is used for long-term anticoagulation.
  • Requires INR monitoring and slower onset of action.
  • Though safe in lactation, it’s not ideal immediately after delivery.

 

Option C. Early ambulation: Incorrect. Recommended for all postpartum women, but not sufficient in high-risk cases like obesity + preeclampsia + LSCS.

 

Option D. Compression stockings: Incorrect. Useful as an adjunct, but insufficient without pharmacologic prophylaxis in high-risk patients.

questions.text: A G2P1L1 suffers cord prolapse during labour. Cervix was 5 cm dilated and cord pulsations were present. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LSCS

 

Umbilical cord prolapse is an obstetric emergency in which the umbilical cord slips below the presenting part, leading to cord compression and fetal hypoxia.


In this case, since:

 

  • The cervix is only 5 cm dilated (not fully dilated), and
  • Cord pulsations are still present (fetus is alive),

 

the immediate priority is to deliver the baby as quickly as possible — and the safest and fastest method in this scenario is an emergency LSCS.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Empty the bladder: Incorrect (but can be a temporary measure). Filling the bladder (not emptying) using Vesicovaginal Bladder Filling or Vago–Bladder Lift technique (O’Driscoll’s method) can temporarily relieve cord compression, but definitive management is delivery by LSCS.

 

Option B. Reverse Trendelenburg: Incorrect. The recommended position is knee–chest or steep Trendelenburg, not reverse. These postures relieve cord compression by gravity.

 

Option D. Funic maneuver: Incorrect.  Refers to manually pushing the cord above the presenting part. Not recommended now.

choices.text: Immediate referral to a cardiologist to control BP

questions.text: A 55-year post-menopausal woman presents to the OPD for a routine BP checkup. Her BP was 170/100 mmHg. She also complains of bloodstained discharge per vagina. What is the next best step of management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) TVS

 

In a postmenopausal woman presenting with blood-stained vaginal discharge or bleeding, the first and most appropriate investigation is Transvaginal Sonography (TVS) to assess endometrial thickness and morphology.

 

  • TVS helps to:
    • Measure endometrial thickness (ET).
    • Identify focal lesions (e.g., polyps, hyperplasia, carcinoma).
    • Guide the need for endometrial sampling or biopsy.
  • Interpretation of endometrial thickness:
  • ET ≤ 4 mm: Low risk of malignancy → Observation or follow-up.
  • ET > 4 mm: Suspicious → Proceed to endometrial biopsy / sampling for histopathology.

 

Thus, the next best step is TVS before planning further evaluation or surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pap smear: Incorrect.

 

  • Pap smear screens for cervical carcinoma, not endometrial pathology.
  • Postmenopausal bleeding is more suggestive of endometrial disease; Pap smear is not diagnostic here.

 

Option B. Immediate referral to a cardiologist to control BP: Incorrect.

 

  • While hypertension (170/100 mmHg) needs attention, it is not the immediate priority in the context of postmenopausal bleeding, which could indicate malignancy.
  • BP control can be done concurrently, but evaluation of bleeding comes first.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy: Incorrect.
 

  • Not done without prior diagnostic confirmation.
  • Indicated only after confirming malignancy or severe premalignant lesion on biopsy.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with amenorrhea for 1 year. She had elevated gonadotropic hormones and decreased AMH. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Premature ovarian insufficiency

 

The combination of amenorrhea, high gonadotropin levels (↑ FSH, ↑ LH), and low AMH (Anti-Müllerian Hormone) indicates ovarian failure — i.e., the ovaries are no longer producing adequate estrogen or viable follicles despite the young age of the woman.


This condition is known as Premature Ovarian Insufficiency (POI) (also called premature ovarian failure).

 

  • Diagnostic criteria:
    • Age <40 years
    • Amenorrhea >4–6 months
    • Elevated FSH (>40 IU/L) on two occasions, 4 weeks apart
    • Low estradiol and low AMH (reflecting reduced ovarian reserve)

 

  • Etiologies include:
    • Genetic (Turner’s, Fragile X premutation)
    • Autoimmune (thyroid, adrenal, ovarian antibodies)
    • Iatrogenic (chemotherapy, radiotherapy)
    • Idiopathic

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PCOS: Incorrect.

 

  • In Polycystic Ovary Syndrome, AMH is elevated due to increased small antral follicles.
  • Gonadotropins show normal or mildly elevated LH, but FSH is low/normal — not high.

 

Option C. Hyperprolactinaemia: Incorrect.

 

  • Causes hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (↓FSH, ↓LH) due to prolactin inhibition of GnRH.
  • AMH levels are usually normal.

 

Option D. Sheehan syndrome: Incorrect.

 

  • Postpartum pituitary necrosis → low gonadotropins (↓FSH, ↓LH) due to pituitary failure.
  • AMH may remain normal initially as ovarian reserve is not directly destroyed.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with delayed cycles and heavy bleeding for the past year. Ultrasonography shows an endometrial thickness of 16 mm. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Endometrial biopsy

 

A 45-year-old woman with heavy menstrual bleeding and thickened endometrium (16 mm) on ultrasound is most likely in the perimenopausal age group.


At this age, anovulatory cycles and unopposed estrogen exposure increase the risk of endometrial hyperplasia or carcinoma.

 

Therefore, the next best step is to perform an endometrial biopsy to rule out endometrial hyperplasia or malignancy before initiating any hormonal or surgical treatment.

 

Indications for endometrial biopsy in abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB):

 

  • Age ≥45 years with AUB
  • Endometrial thickness >12 mm in premenopausal or >4–5 mm in postmenopausal women
  • Risk factors: obesity, diabetes, PCOS, chronic anovulation, tamoxifen use, unopposed estrogen

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start OCPs: Incorrect.

 

  • Hormonal therapy (like OCPs or progestins) may be used for dysfunctional uterine bleeding, but only after excluding malignancy.
  • Starting OCPs before histologic confirmation risks delaying diagnosis of endometrial carcinoma.

 

Option B. Wait and watch for 6 months: Incorrect.

 

  • Observation is unsafe when ET >16 mm and the patient is >40 years with heavy bleeding.
  • There is a significant risk of endometrial pathology.

 

Option C. Hysterectomy: Incorrect.

 

  • This is definitive treatment only after diagnosis (e.g., confirmed hyperplasia with atypia or carcinoma).
  • Not the next immediate step.

choices.text: Most commonly spreads directly from fallopian tubes
Hematogenous spread can occur from pulmonary focus
Hematogeneous spread is the commonest mode of transmission
May rarely occur due to infected semen from partner with genitourinary TB

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with infertility. Endometrial biopsy reveals tuberculosis. Regarding the mode of spread of endometrial tuberculosis, all of the following are true except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hematogeneous spread is the commonest mode of transmission

 

Although genital tuberculosis as a whole is usually seeded hematogenously from a distant focus(usually-lungs),the endometrial involvement specifically is secondary, caused by direct spread from the fallopian tubes, not primarily hematogenous.

 

In other words:

 

  • The genital tract gets infected by hematogenous spread initially (starting in tubes).
  • But the endometrium itself gets infected by direct extension from the tubal lesion.

 

Hence, when the question asks about endometrial tuberculosis,
the commonest mode of spread to the endometrium is direct spread from infected tubes, and not hematogenous spread.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Most commonly spreads directly from fallopian tubes: True.

 

  • Endometrial TB almost always follows tubal infection via direct extension.
  • The endometrium is rarely the initial site.

 

Option B. Hematogenous spread can occur from pulmonary focus: True. That is the initial route for infection reaching the genital tract, but not the main route for endometrial involvement.

 

Option D. May rarely occur due to infected semen from partner with genitourinary TB: True. A very rare but documented route (venereal transmission).

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to primary amenorrhea. The patient had ambiguous external genitalia noted at birth, and laparotomy performed at 17 months of age revealed a normal uterus and fallopian tubes. Ovarian biopsy performed at that time revealed normal-appearing primordial follicles. Blood pressure is 120/78 mm Hg and height is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in). The patient has nodulocystic acne over the chest and back. No breast development, normal pubic and axillary hair, and marked clitoromegaly are present. Laboratory results show a normal female karyotype and normal glucose and serum electrolytes. Serum FSH, LH, testosterone, and androstenedione concentrations are high. Pelvic imaging reveals multiple ovarian cysts. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aromatase deficiency

 

This 18-year-old woman has:

 

  • Primary amenorrhea
  • Normal female karyotype (46,XX)
  • Normal uterus and ovaries with follicles
  • Virilization (clitoromegaly, acne, no breast development)
  • High FSH, LH, testosterone, and androstenedione
  • Normal electrolytes and blood pressure

 

These findings are classical of Aromatase Deficiency, a rare cause of primary amenorrhea with virilization in 46,XX females.

 

Pathophysiology:

 

Aromatase enzyme (CYP19 gene) converts androgens → estrogens in:

 

  • Ovaries (granulosa cells)
  • Placenta
  • Adipose tissue
  • In Aromatase deficiency:

 

  • Conversion of testosterone and androstenedione to estrogen fails → ↓ estrogen.
  • Excess androgens accumulate → virilization in female fetus and after puberty.
  • Lack of estrogen → no breast development, primary amenorrhea, high gonadotropins (FSH, LH) due to loss of negative feedback.
  • Ovaries become multicystic due to chronic stimulation by FSH/LH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia: Incorrect.

 

  • Usually presents with electrolyte disturbances (low Na⁺, high K⁺) if 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  • Elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone, not seen here.
  • Ovaries are normal; uterus normal but androgen excess is adrenal in origin, not ovarian.

 

Option C. Kallmann syndrome: Incorrect.

 

  • Caused by GnRH deficiency → low FSH, low LH, low estrogen.
  • No virilization, no acne, no androgen excess. Associated with anosmia.

 

Option D. Swyer syndrome (46,XY gonadal dysgenesis): Incorrect.

 

  • Karyotype is 46,XY, not 46,XX.
  • Has streak gonads, not normal ovaries.
  • No virilization, since no androgen production.

 

Summary Table:

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman undergoes in vitro fertilization (IVF) and Embryo transfer is performed after the third day of fertilization. Based on this information, what is the estimated date of delivery (EDD) from the date of embryo transfer?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 263 days

 

In In Vitro Fertilization (IVF), the Embryo Transfer (ET) date is not equivalent to the date of conception, because fertilization has already occurred in vitro before the embryo is transferred back to the uterus.

 

The Estimated Date of Delivery (EDD) in IVF cases is therefore calculated from the date of embryo transfer, adjusted for the embryo’s developmental age.

 

Key Concept:

 

 

So, in this case —

 

  • Embryo transfer = Day 3 embryo,
    → Expected due date = Embryo transfer date + 261 days.

questions.text: A G2P1L1 with a history of previous caesarean section presented in active labour. During trial of labour, there was foetal bradycardia and maternal tachycardia. Persistent suprapubic pain between contractions was also noted. On examination, cervix was 8 cm dilated and the vertex was at –1 station. What is the next best step of management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Emergency Lower segment caesarean section

 

The woman is a G2P1L1 with previous caesarean section, now in active labour and showing signs of scar dehiscence— a life-threatening obstetric emergency.

 

Key clues in the question:

 

  • Previous LSCS → uterine scar present (risk of rupture during TOLAC).
  • Fetal bradycardia → most sensitive and early sign of uterine rupture.
  • Maternal tachycardia → suggests maternal shock or concealed bleeding.
  • Persistent suprapubic pain between contractions → classic sign of impending or actual rupture (constant, non-labour pain).
  • Cervix 8 cm, vertex –1 station → not imminent vaginal delivery.

 

Thus, this is a case of suspected uterine rupture, requiring immediate emergency laparotomy and LSCS to deliver the baby and control bleeding.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Instrumental delivery: Incorrect. Cervix is 8 cm dilated and vertex is –1 station — Instrumental contraindicated when uterine rupture is suspected; vaginal delivery attempts can worsen rupture.

 

Option C. Stop oxytocin: Incorrect (but supportive step). Oxytocin should indeed be stopped if being used, but this alone is not sufficient. Definitive management is emergency surgery.

 

Option D. Artificial rupture of membranes: Incorrect. Contraindicated; can precipitate complete rupture and worsen maternal/foetal compromise.

questions.text: A primigravida at 37 weeks presents with decreased foetal movements for 1 day. NST showed one acceleration in 20 minutes and no decelerations. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Repeat NST

 

In this case:

 

  • The patient is 37 weeks pregnant,
  • Complains of decreased fetal movements,
  • NST (Non-Stress Test) shows 1 acceleration in 20 minutes, and no decelerations.

 

This finding means the NST is “non-reactive but non-reassuring” — it is equivocal, not abnormal, and therefore requires repeat testing before further interventions.

 

A reactive NST requires ≥2 accelerations (each ≥15 bpm above baseline lasting ≥15 seconds) within 20 minutes.


If this criterion is not met, but there are no decelerations, the test is indeterminate, and the next appropriate step is to extend or repeat the NST (up to 40 minutes or after some time).

 

Rationale for Next Step:

 

  • Fetus may be in a sleep cycle lasting 20–40 minutes → causing reduced accelerations.
  • Repeating the NST after a short interval or extending it for another 20 minutes helps confirm reactivity.
  • Immediate interventions (like induction or Doppler) are done only if NST remains non-reactive or abnormal on repetition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Induce labour immediately: Incorrect.
 

  • Immediate induction is indicated only if NST remains persistently non-reactive with abnormal BPP or Doppler findings suggesting foetal compromise.
  • Here, the NST is non-reactive but not ominous.

 

Option C. USG Doppler for umbilical artery: Incorrect.
 

  • Umbilical artery Doppler is indicated if repeated NSTs are non-reactive or suspicious or if IUGR / preeclampsia is suspected.
  • Not the immediate next step.

 

Option D. Modified BPP: Incorrect.

 

  • Modified Biophysical Profile (NST + Amniotic Fluid Index) is done after a repeated non-reactive NST.
  • It is the next investigation if NST remains non-reactive.

 

REACTIVE NST:-

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, at 40 weeks gestation comes to the hospital due to painful contractions for the past few hours. The patient has had no leakage of fluid or vaginal bleeding. Fetal movement has been normal. On admission, the cervix is 5 cm dilated and 90% effaced with the fetal head at -1 station. She received epidural analgesia; on repeat cervical examination, the cervix is 6 cm dilated and 100% effaced with the fetal head at -1 station. Two hours later, the cervix is unchanged. Fetal heart rate monitoring shows a baseline of 130/min, moderate variability, accelerations, and occasional early decelerations. The tocodynamometer shows contractions every 5-7 minutes. Which of the following is the best next step is management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oxytocin infusion

 

This patient is in active labor (≥6 cm dilatation) but has had no cervical progress for 2 hours.


Fetal heart tracing is reassuring, and contractions are infrequent (every 5–7 minutes) — this indicates inadequate uterine activity rather than true arrest.

 

Hence, the best next step is to augment labor with oxytocin infusion to increase contraction frequency and strength.

 

Stepwise Reasoning

 

1. Labor phase:

 

  • At 6 cm → she is in active phase of the first stage of labor.

 

2. Definition of arrest vs protraction (per ACOG 2020):

 

 

Here:

 

  • Cervix unchanged for 2 hours
  • Contractions inadequate (every 5–7 min)
    → Protraction of active phase, not yet arrest.

 

Hence, the appropriate management is oxytocin augmentation.

 

Other Findings Supporting This Decision

 

  • FHR tracing: Baseline 130/min, moderate variability, accelerations, and early decelerations → Category I (normal) → fetus is fine.
  • Epidural analgesia: Can sometimes decrease contraction frequency, which can be corrected by oxytocin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cesarean delivery: Incorrect.
 

  • Indicated only if active phase arrest (no progress for ≥4 hrs with adequate contractions or ≥6 hrs with inadequate contractions).
  • Here only 2 hrs have passed with poor contractions.

 

Option B. Continue expectant management: Incorrect.
 

  • She already shows slow progress and weak contractions; continuing without augmentation prolongs labor and increases risk of infection and exhaustion.

 

Option D. Vaginal misoprostol: Incorrect.
 

  • Used for cervical ripening in induction, not for augmentation in active labor.
  • Contraindicated once in active phase and with regular contractions.

choices.text: Wait for spontaneous onset of labor

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman at term is admitted for normal vaginal delivery. Her per vaginal examination shows a cervix dilatation of 5 cm and cord prolapse with absent FHR on examination. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Wait for spontaneous onset of labor

 

In cord prolapse with absent fetal heart sounds, the fetus is dead.
So, the goal is safe delivery for the mother, not fetal rescue.

 

However — in this case:

 

  • The cervix is only 5 cm dilated,
  • Active labor has begun, but not yet full dilatation,
  • The fetus is dead,
    → Hence, there is no need for cesarean section or operative acceleration.

 

The safest management is to allow labor to progress naturally (expectant management) until full dilatation, followed by spontaneous vaginal delivery.
No active induction or instrumentation is required at this stage.

 

Stepwise Logic

 

 

➡ Therefore, wait for spontaneous progress of labor and deliver vaginally.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate cesarean section: Incorrect.
 

  • Indicated only when fetus is alive and can be saved.
  • Not indicated once FHR is absent (IUFD).

 

Option B. Start LMWH followed by LSCS: Incorrect.
 

  • Irrelevant to obstetric emergency; LMWH has no role in cord prolapse. It is used in cases of thromboprophylaxis in pregnancy.

 

Option C. Vaginal delivery by forceps extraction: Incorrect.
 

  • Cervix only 5 cm — not fully dilated, so forceps delivery cannot be done.
  • Forceps may be used later after full dilatation if delivery needs to be expedited, but not immediately.

choices.text: Pregnancy is safe with lifestyle modifications
Pregnancy is safe with close monitoring and medical management
Pregnancy is safe as any general population

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with a history of peripartum cardiomyopathy following a previous pregnancy presents for preconception counselling. Her current ECHO reveals an ejection fraction of 45%. What would be the best advice for her regarding upcoming pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pregnancy is contraindicated

 

Peripartum cardiomyopathy (PPCM) is a type of dilated cardiomyopathy that occurs during the last month of pregnancy or within 5 months postpartum, in a woman with no prior cardiac disease.

 

The most important predictor of maternal outcome in future pregnancies is left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) after recovery from the initial episode.

 

Risk Stratification Based on Current Ejection Fraction (ECHO):

questions.text:
Arrange the following sites of endometriosis in decreasing order of frequency of involvement:

 

  1. Pouch of Douglas
  2. Uterosacral ligament
  3. Broad ligament
  4. Ovary
  5. Fallopian tube
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4 > 1 > 3 > 2 > 5

 

Endometriosis refers to the presence of functional endometrial glands and stroma outside the uterine cavity.


It most commonly involves dependent pelvic structures where retrograde menstrual blood tends to collect.

 

The most frequent sites of endometriosis, in decreasing order of involvement, are:

choices.text: It is associated with obesity and diabetes

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding Type I endometrial carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Smoking is a high-risk factor

 

Type I Endometrial Carcinoma (also called Endometrioid type) is the most common type of endometrial cancer, accounting for about 80–85% of cases.


It is estrogen-dependent and arises from endometrial hyperplasia due to unopposed estrogen exposure.

 

Smoking and Endometrial Cancer

 

  • Smoking is NOT a risk factor for endometrial carcinoma.
  • In fact, smoking is paradoxically associated with a reduced risk of Type I endometrial cancer due to anti-estrogenic effects of smoking (it increases hepatic metabolism of estrogen).

 

Hence, the statement “Smoking is a high-risk factor” is incorrect.

questions.text: In which of the following stages of puberty does estrogen not have a major role?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pubarche

 

Puberty is the sequence of events leading to sexual maturation and reproductive capability, regulated by activation of the hypothalamic–pituitary–gonadal (HPG) axis.


Different hormones dominate at different stages of pubertal development.

 

  • Pubarche results from adrenarche — increased secretion of adrenal androgens (DHEA, DHEAS, androstenedione) from the zona reticularis of adrenal cortex. Responsible for pubic and axillary hair growth, body odor, and mild acne.
  • Estrogen does not play a major role here.
  • Estrogen dominates in thelarche, menarche, and growth spurt (through its skeletal and endometrial effects).

 

Stages of Puberty and Their Hormonal Control:

choices.text: Fetal fibronectin and lung maturity testing

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, at 26 weeks gestation comes to the emergency department due to intermittent leakage of fluid for the past 6 hours. She has had no vaginal bleeding or contractions. The patient's previous pregnancy was complicated by preterm prelabor rupture of membranes at 29 weeks gestation; she delivered at 34 weeks gestation after inpatient management with corticosteroids and latency antibiotics. Temperature is 39.4°C (103°F), blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg, and pulse is 114/min. Fetal heart rate is 170/min. The cervix is 2 cm dilated. In addition to antibiotics and steroids which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immediate induction of labor

 

This patient has preterm prelabor rupture of membranes (PPROM) at 26 weeks gestation, now complicated by:

 

  • High-grade fever (39.4°C)
  • Maternal tachycardia (114/min)
  • Fetal tachycardia (170/min)

 

These are classic signs of chorioamnionitis (intraamniotic infection) — the most serious complication of PPROM.

 

Once chorioamnionitis is diagnosed, immediate delivery is indicated, irrespective of gestational age, because continued pregnancy endangers both mother and fetus. Continue broad-spectrum IV antibiotics (ampicillin + gentamicin ± clindamycin/metronidazole).

 

Stepwise Reasoning

 

1. Diagnosis:

 

  • PPROM: Leakage of amniotic fluid before labor and before 37 weeks.
  • Chorioamnionitis indicators:
    • Maternal fever ≥38°C
    • Maternal tachycardia (>100/min)
    • Fetal tachycardia (>160/min)
    • Uterine tenderness or foul-smelling amniotic fluid

 

Here, the patient meets multiple criteria → confirmed chorioamnionitis.

 

2. Management of PPROM 

 

 

Thus, since infection is present, delivery is mandatory now.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fetal fibronectin and lung maturity testing: Incorrect.

 

  • Used to assess risk of preterm delivery or fetal readiness when no infection is present.
  • In chorioamnionitis, there’s no role for delaying delivery.

 

Option C. Tocolysis: Incorrect. Contraindicated in the presence of infection; it worsens maternal sepsis risk.

 

Option D. Serial fetal ultrasounds and amnioinfusion: Incorrect. Used in expectant management without infection, not indicated when chorioamnionitis is suspected.

questions.text: An ultrasound confirms an anterior placenta covering the cervical os and an amniotic fluid index of 1.5 with a single fluid pocket measuring 1.5 x 1 cm. Over a period of 45 minutes, there are 4 episodes of fetal movement, 3 flexion/extension events, and no fetal breathing movements. The fetus is breech. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's biophysical ultrasound findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Placental insufficiency

 

Chronic placental insufficiency results from poor uteroplacental perfusion, leading to progressive fetal hypoxemia and nutrient deprivation. The fetus prioritizes vital organ perfusion (brain, heart, adrenals) through blood flow redistribution, causing decreased renal perfusion and reduced urine production, resulting in oligohydramnios. Diminished fetal breathing and movements on biophysical profile reflect adaptive hypometabolic activity in response to hypoxia, characteristic of placental dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fetal malpresentation: Such as breech affects only the orientation of the fetus within the uterus and does not impair fetal oxygenation, tone, or amniotic fluid production. The observed abnormal BPP parameters cannot be explained by fetal lie alone.

 

Option B. Maternal hypoglycemia: can transiently decrease fetal movements due to temporary energy deprivation but resolves once glucose levels normalize. It does not cause sustained low amniotic fluid or persistent abnormal biophysical findings, which suggest chronic pathology.

 

Option D. Placental location: (anterior placenta) influences where the placenta attaches within the uterus and may make fetal movements harder to feel or visualize. However, it has no physiological impact on fetal oxygenation, breathing activity, or amniotic fluid volume, and therefore cannot account for the abnormal BPP findings.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman, gravida 5 para 0 aborta 4, at 35 weeks gestation comes to labor and delivery triage because she has not felt her baby move for the past 24 hours. The patient has not eaten much all day and skipped dinner due to nausea. She has a 25-pack-year history of cigarette use but has cut down on her smoking during her pregnancy. Her last ultrasound at 32 weeks gestation showed a fetus in breech position measuring at the 15th percentile and placenta previa. A nonstress test shows a baseline fetal heart rate in the 130s with moderate variability and no decelerations. There are no accelerations after an hour of monitoring despite vibroacoustic stimulation. Tocometry shows no contractions. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Biophysical profile

 

A nonstress test (NST) without accelerations after adequate observation and vibroacoustic stimulation is considered nonreactive. In this patient at 35 weeks with risk factors such as cigarette use, fetal growth restriction, and placenta previa, the next step is to assess overall fetal well-being using a biophysical profile (BPP). BPP evaluates five parameters—NST, fetal breathing, body movements, tone, and amniotic fluid volume—to determine if fetal hypoxemia or placental insufficiency is present. It helps decide whether to continue expectant management or proceed with delivery based on the score.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cesarean delivery: Is not indicated immediately because the current NST shows no decelerations, suggesting no acute fetal distress. Delivery is reserved for evidence of fetal compromise on further testing.

 

Option C. Contraction stress test: Assesses fetal heart rate response to uterine contractions but is contraindicated in placenta previa because contractions may cause bleeding.

 

Option D. Umbilical artery flow velocimetry: Is mainly used for monitoring known growth-restricted fetuses to assess placental resistance, but it is not the next step after a nonreactive NST; BPP provides a more comprehensive assessment first.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, at 36 weeks gestation presents to the hospital for a blood pressure of 190/110 mm Hg in the office. Initial laboratory results show elevated serum creatinine and transaminases. Nifedipine, magnesium sulfate, are administered. Induction of labor is started with oxytocin. Six hours later, the patient's blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. The patient now complaints of nausea, headache, generalized muscle weakness and respiratory distress. DTRs are absent. What is the likely cause of the findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Renal insufficiency

 

This patient with severe preeclampsia was treated with magnesium sulfate for seizure prophylaxis. Magnesium is excreted almost entirely by the kidneys, and her elevated creatinine indicates renal impairment, causing reduced magnesium clearance. Accumulation of magnesium leads to toxicity characterized by nausea, weakness, loss of deep tendon reflexes, respiratory depression, and potentially cardiac arrest. Therefore, renal insufficiency is the likely cause of these findings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Drug-drug interaction: Is unlikely because nifedipine and magnesium are commonly co-administered in preeclampsia and do not produce this classical toxicity pattern at therapeutic doses.

 

Option B. Hypocalcemia: May cause muscle cramps and tetany but not generalized muscle weakness with absent reflexes and respiratory depression. Moreover, it would not develop so acutely after magnesium therapy.

 

Option C. Oxytocin toxicity: Presents with hyponatremia and water intoxication symptoms such as seizures and confusion, not absent reflexes or respiratory muscle paralysis as seen here with magnesium toxicity secondary to renal dysfunction.

choices.text: Inhibition of maintenance of corpus luteum
Inhibition of ovulation by suppressing LH surge
Thickening of the endometrium to prevent implantation

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary mode of action of ulipristal 30mg in emergency contraception?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inhibition of ovulation by suppressing LH surge

 

Ulipristal acetate (30 mg), a selective progesterone receptor modulator (SPRM), acts primarily by delaying or inhibiting ovulation. It works by binding to progesterone receptors and blocking the preovulatory luteinizing hormone (LH) surge, thereby preventing follicular rupture and ovum release. When taken before ovulation, it is highly effective as an emergency contraceptive, preventing fertilization by stopping ovulation altogether.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibition of maintenance of corpus luteum: Is not the main mechanism; corpus luteum suppression is more relevant to long-term progesterone antagonism, not single-dose emergency use.

 

Option B. Interference with sperm penetration: Is the mechanism of levonorgestrel or copper IUD, not ulipristal, which acts primarily at the level of ovulation.

 

Option D. Thickening of the endometrium to prevent implantation: Ulipristal may alter endometrial receptivity secondarily, but this is not its primary or reliable mechanism for Emergency contraception. Thickening of endometrium (making it less receptive for implantation) is the MOA of Combined estrogen–progestin OCPs (secondary effect).

 

LIST OF CONTRACEPTIVES and their MOA:

 

  • HORMONAL CONTRACEPTIVES MOA:

 

 

  • INTRAUTERINE CONTRACEPTIVE DEVICES (IUCDs) MOA:

 

 

  • BARRIER METHODS MOA:

 

 

  • OTHER / SPECIAL METHODS and their MOA:

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, at 8 weeks gestation comes to the office for a follow-up visit. Earlier in the pregnancy, the patient had nausea and breast tenderness that resolved several days ago. At her initial prenatal visit a week ago, ultrasound revealed an intrauterine gestational sac with a yolk sac but no fetal pole. Pelvic examination reveals a closed cervix and no vaginal discharge or bleeding. A transvaginal ultrasound is repeated and is unchanged from the prior visit. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Missed abortion

 

A missed abortion refers to intrauterine fetal death before 20 weeks gestation without expulsion of the products of conception. This patient initially had early pregnancy symptoms (nausea, breast tenderness) that have resolved, suggesting loss of hormonal support. Ultrasound showing a gestational sac with a yolk sac but no fetal pole on two scans a week apart confirms absence of fetal development, indicating embryonic demise. The closed cervix and absence of bleeding or tissue passage further support the diagnosis of a missed abortion.

 

Early pregnancy failure:

 

Gsac > 25mm with no fetal pole

 

CRL >7mm with no FHR

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ectopic pregnancy: Typically shows no intrauterine gestational sac and often presents with abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, or an adnexal mass; an intrauterine sac rules this out.

 

Option B. Hydatidiform mole: Presents with markedly elevated β-hCG, uterine size greater than gestational age, and a “snowstorm” pattern on ultrasound, not a gestational sac with yolk sac and no fetal pole.

 

Option D. Threatened abortion: Involves vaginal bleeding with a closed cervix and viable embryo; this patient has no bleeding and no fetal pole, indicating nonviable pregnancy rather than a threatened one.

questions.text: A 17-year-old adolescent presents to the gynecology clinic with a history of severe menstrual pain and recurrent pelvic infections since the onset of menstruation. She reports cyclical pain coinciding with her menstrual periods and has experienced occasional urinary tract infections. On physical examination, there is a palpable pelvic mass. Ultrasound imaging reveals a duplicated uterine cavity with one side showing an hematometra and absence of the left kidney. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Herlyn-Werner-Wunderlich syndrome

 

Herlyn-Werner-Wunderlich syndrome, also known as Obstructed Hemivagina and Ipsilateral Renal Agenesis (OHVIRA) syndrome, is a rare congenital Müllerian duct anomaly. It is characterized by a triad of uterus didelphys (double uterus), obstructed hemivagina leading to hematometra or hematocolpos, and absence of the ipsilateral kidney. The patient’s cyclical pain since menarche, pelvic mass due to hematometra, and ultrasound showing uterine duplication with unilateral renal agenesis are classic features of this condition.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) Syndrome: Presents with congenital absence of the uterus and upper two-thirds of the vagina, leading to primary amenorrhea, not cyclical pain or hematometra.

 

Option B. Asherman’s Syndrome: Occurs due to intrauterine adhesions following uterine curettage or infection, causing secondary amenorrhea and infertility, not congenital anomalies.

 

Option D. Endometriosis: Results from ectopic endometrial tissue causing dysmenorrhea and infertility, but it does not present with uterine duplication or renal agenesis on imaging.

 

Below is an example of a patient who was diagnosed with OHVIRA syndrome:

 

 

A to D: (A) and (B) Contrast-enhanced axial CT image of pelvis shows two separate uterine cavities suggestive of didelphic uterus 

 

(C) Inferior section of the pelvis showing two vaginal cavities separated by a longitudinal septum with distended right hemivagina suggestive of right hematocolpos

 

(D)-Coronal reconstructed image of CT abdomen with absent right kidney

questions.text: An athlete with a BMI of 17.5 kg/m2 presents with secondary amenorrhea and primary infertility. Her laboratory investigations reveal FSH 2; LH 0.3; TSH 1.2; Prolactin 20 ng/ml. What is the underlying cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism

 

This patient’s low BMI, secondary amenorrhea, and infertility suggest functional hypothalamic amenorrhea due to energy deficiency from excessive exercise or inadequate caloric intake. The laboratory findings show low FSH and LH with normal TSH and prolactin, confirming suppression of the hypothalamic–pituitary–gonadal axis. Decreased pulsatile GnRH secretion leads to reduced gonadotropin levels, causing anovulation and hypoestrogenism—typical of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Primary ovarian failure: Would present with elevated FSH and LH due to loss of ovarian feedback inhibition, unlike the low levels seen here.

 

Option C. Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism: Also features high gonadotropins with low estrogen, commonly due to ovarian failure or gonadal dysgenesis, not seen in this athlete.


Option D. Normogonadotropic normogonadism: Occurs in conditions such as polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), where FSH and LH levels are normal or mildly elevated, not suppressed as in this case.

choices.text: Attachment of the placenta onto the myometrium
Injury to the fetal placental vessels

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida at 37 weeks gestation is brought to the emergency department with constant, excruciating abdominal pain and sudden vaginal bleeding for the past 3 hours. The patient is Rh negative and received Rh(D) immunoglobulin at 28 weeks gestation. Blood pressure is 160/100 mm Hg and pulse is 118/min. Physical examination shows a firm and tender uterus. Speculum examination reveals a moderate amount of bleeding coming from an open cervical os. Fetal heart tracing shows a baseline of 105/min and no variability. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's bleeding?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Premature placental separation

 

Premature placental separation, or placental abruption, occurs when the placenta detaches from the uterine wall before delivery, leading to painful vaginal bleeding, uterine tenderness, and fetal distress. The patient’s severe, constant abdominal pain, firm tender uterus, hypertension, and non-reassuring foetal heart pattern (bradycardia with absent variability) are classic findings. The bleeding is typically dark and may be accompanied by concealed hemorrhage, making the uterus tense and rigid. Chronic hypertension and preeclampsia are key risk factors, as seen here with elevated blood pressure.

 

 

Abruptio placentae:

 

A. Mild abruption with concealed hemorrhage. B. Severe abruption with external hemorrhage. C, Complete separation with concealed hemorrhage.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Attachment of the placenta onto the myometrium (placenta accreta): Presents with adherent placenta and severe postpartum hemorrhage at delivery, not antepartum pain or bleeding.
 

Option B. Injury to fetal placental vessels (vasa previa): Causes painless, rapid fetal exsanguination with bright red bleeding at membrane rupture, not a tender, firm uterus.
 

Option C. Placental implantation over the cervix (placenta previa): Results in painless, bright red bleeding and a soft, nontender uterus; pain and uterine rigidity are absent.

questions.text: An 18-year-old primigravida at 27 weeks gestation comes to the emergency department due to severe right upper quadrant pain. The pain started 2 hours ago, and the patient has also had nausea, vomiting, and irregular uterine contractions. Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT) is 220 U/L and alanine aminotransferase (SGPT) is 240 U/L. CECT is shown below. This patient is most likely at risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Seizures

 

The CT image shows a subcapsular hepatic hematoma, which is a severe complication of HELLP syndrome (Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, and Low Platelets)—a variant of severe preeclampsia. The patient’s presentation of right upper quadrant pain, elevated transaminases, nausea, and vomiting during pregnancy strongly suggests this diagnosis. The hematoma results from hepatic sinusoidal distention and rupture of subcapsular vessels due to endothelial damage. As HELLP is a manifestation of severe preeclampsia, the patient is at high risk of developing eclampsia (seizures) if not promptly managed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute interstitial nephritis: Is a hypersensitivity reaction caused by medications such as antibiotics or NSAIDs, characterized by fever, rash, and eosinophiluria. In HELLP syndrome, renal injury results instead from preeclampsia-induced vasospasm and glomerular endotheliosis, not from an allergic or drug-related mechanism.

 

Option B. Bleeding esophageal varices: Occur as a consequence of portal hypertension from chronic liver disease such as cirrhosis. HELLP syndrome causes acute hepatic injury and subcapsular hematoma but not chronic fibrosis or portal hypertension, so variceal bleeding is not a risk here.

 

Option C. Intraamniotic infection (chorioamnionitis): Typically presents with maternal fever, uterine tenderness, foul-smelling amniotic fluid, and fetal tachycardia. This patient’s presentation of severe right upper quadrant pain and elevated liver enzymes is unrelated to infection and instead points toward hepatic vascular injury secondary to preeclampsia.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old girl presents with irregular menstrual cycles. According to the Rotterdam criteria, which of the following are diagnostic for PCOS?


a. Obesity
b. Delayed periods
c. Hirsutism
d. Insulin resistance
questions.solution:
Ans. B) b and c

 

According to the Rotterdam criteria , a diagnosis of Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) requires at least two of the following three features after exclusion of other causes:

 

  1. Oligo- or anovulation → manifests as irregular or delayed periods
  2. Clinical or biochemical hyperandrogenism → presents as hirsutism, acne, or androgenic alopecia
  3. Polycystic ovaries on ultrasound (≥12 follicles measuring 2–9 mm in diameter and/or increased ovarian volume >10 cm³)

 

While obesity and insulin resistance are commonly associated with PCOS, they are not diagnostic criteria per Rotterdam. Therefore, delayed periods and hirsutism are the defining features from the options given.

choices.text: Placenta previa should be ruled out
Uterine diadelphys is likely in the patient
There are high chances of cord prolapse in the patient

questions.text: A multiparous woman is in labor at 38 weeks of gestation. On examination, the uterus appears asymmetrical. In fundal grip, the fetal pole is not palpable and in pelvic grip, the lower pole of the uterus is empty. All of the following are true about the given presentation except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Uterine diadelphys is likely in the patient

 

The findings described—an asymmetrical uterus, absent fetal pole in both fundal and pelvic grips, and an empty lower uterine segment—are characteristic of a transverse lie presentation. In this condition, the fetus lies horizontally in the uterus, with the shoulder presenting at the pelvic inlet. Uterine diadelphys (a congenital anomaly with a double uterus) is not associated with this typical presentation and is therefore not the likely cause. The asymmetry seen here results from the abnormal fetal lie, not a uterine malformation.

 

Other Options:


Option A) Placenta previa should be ruled out: Because low-lying placenta can prevent fetal engagement and predispose to transverse lie, warranting ultrasound confirmation.
 

Option C) There are high chances of cord prolapse in the patient: As the presenting part does not fill the pelvic inlet, allowing the cord to slip past the fetus during membrane rupture.
 

Option D) Elective LSCS should be performed: Because transverse lie at term is not compatible with vaginal delivery; cesarean section is the safest mode of delivery.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the OPD by her mother because she has not started menstruating. Height is at the 15th percentile and weight is at the 20th percentile for age. Vital signs are normal. There is no breast development or axillary hair. Pelvic examination reveals normal external female genitalia and no pubic hair. Ultrasound confirms the presence of a uterus. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reassurance

 

In a 12-year-old girl with no breast development or menstruation but otherwise normal growth parameters and normal uterine anatomy on ultrasound, reassurance and continued observation are appropriate. Pubertal onset (thelarche) typically occurs between 8–13 years, and menarche follows about 2–3 years later. At 12 years, this patient is still within the normal age range for pubertal onset. Since she has normal external genitalia, no signs of systemic disease, and no evidence of delayed skeletal or linear growth, it is best to observe and reassess after some months rather than begin investigations prematurely.

 

Other Options:


Option B. FSH level: Measurement is indicated if the girl shows no pubertal development by age 13 or no menarche by age 15 with normal secondary sexual characteristics. At 12, this evaluation is still early.
 

Option C. Serum β-Hcg: Testing is used when secondary amenorrhea or suspected pregnancy exists, not in a prepubertal girl who has not begun menstruating.
 

Option D. Karyotype analysis: Is done when gonadal dysgenesis or Turner syndrome is suspected, typically if FSH is elevated or other clinical features like short stature or streak gonads are present, which are not seen in this case.

choices.text: Involvement of three or more organs
Development of manifestations in less than a week
Histological evidence of hydropic degeneration of villi
Presence of antiphospholipid antibodies on two occasions six weeks apart

questions.text: Diagnostic criteria for Catastrophic antiphospholipid syndrome includes all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Histological evidence of hydropic degeneration of villi

 

molar pregnancy and has no role in the diagnosis of CAPS, hence it is the incorrect statement.

 

Catastrophic Antiphospholipid Syndrome (CAPS) is a rare, severe, and life-threatening variant of antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APS). It is characterized by widespread microvascular thrombosis leading to multiorgan failure over a very short time (usually less than one week). The underlying mechanism involves excessive activation of endothelial cells, platelets, and the coagulation cascade triggered by antiphospholipid antibodies, resulting in diffuse small-vessel occlusion. CAPS is often precipitated by infections, surgery, trauma, or discontinuation of anticoagulation therapy.

 

Clinically, patients develop rapid organ dysfunction—commonly affecting the kidneys (renal failure), lungs (ARDS), brain (stroke or encephalopathy), heart (myocardial infarction), skin (livedo reticularis), and adrenal glands (insufficiency). Laboratory findings include thrombocytopenia, elevated D-dimer, prolonged APTT (due to lupus anticoagulant), and high titers of antiphospholipid antibodies (anticardiolipin, lupus anticoagulant, or anti-β2 glycoprotein I).

 

Diagnostic criteria for CAPS (Modified Asherson’s Criteria):

 

  1. Involvement of three or more organs, systems, or tissues.
  2. Development of manifestations within one week.
  3. Histopathological evidence of small-vessel occlusion (thrombosis).
  4. Presence of antiphospholipid antibodies on two or more occasions at least six weeks apart.

questions.text: A 14-year-old female presented to you with primary amenorrhea. Examination reveals normal breast development and absent axillary and pubic hairs. Pelvic examination shows a normally developed vagina with clitoromegaly and micro-phallus. On ultrasound, masses are visible in the inguinal region. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Partial androgen insensitivity syndrome

 

Partial Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (PAIS) occurs due to a partial defect in the androgen receptor gene on the X chromosome (X-linked recessive). Individuals have a 46,XY karyotype with normal testes producing testosterone, but the body’s tissues respond incompletely to androgens. The degree of masculinization varies depending on the severity of receptor dysfunction. This patient’s presentation—primary amenorrhea, normal breast development (from aromatization of testosterone to estrogen), clitoromegaly/microphallus, absent pubic and axillary hair, and inguinal masses representing undescended testes—fits the clinical picture of PAIS.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome: Presents with normal breast development, completely female external genitalia, and absent uterus or upper vagina, without any clitoromegaly or ambiguous features.
 

Option B. Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome: Occurs in 46,XX females with normal secondary sexual characteristics but absent uterus and upper vagina; there is no clitoromegaly or inguinal testes.
 

Option D. Gonadal dysgenesis (e.g., Swyer syndrome): Features streak gonads and absence of secondary sexual development due to lack of estrogen; patients have no breast development and present with a normal uterus, which differs from the findings here.

questions.text:
Which of the following are indications of LSCS?

 

1. Brow presentation

2. Mentoposterior position

3. Breech presentation

4. Occipitoposterior position

5. Mentoanterior position
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2

 

Both brow presentation and mentoposterior position are absolute indications for cesarean section because vaginal delivery is mechanically impossible due to the fetal head’s unfavorable attitude and position.

 

In brow presentation, the fetal head is midway between full flexion and full extension, resulting in the largest diameter (mentovertical diameter—13.5 cm) presenting to the birth canal. This diameter cannot pass through the maternal pelvis, so cesarean section is mandatory.

 

In mentoposterior position, the fetal chin (mentum) points posteriorly toward the maternal sacrum. With this orientation, the fetal head cannot extend further to pass under the pubic symphysis, preventing vaginal delivery. Cesarean section is required in all such cases unless spontaneous mentoanterior rotation occurs (which is rare).

 

Explanation of the remaining statements:


3. Breech presentation: This is not an absolute indication for LSCS. Vaginal breech delivery may be possible, especially in multiparous women, small fetuses, or frank breech presentations. However, in primigravidas, large fetuses, or cases with fetal distress, cesarean section is preferred for safety.

 

4. Occipitoposterior position: In this position, the fetal occiput lies posteriorly toward the maternal sacrum. Most cases rotate anteriorly during labor (long anterior rotation) and deliver vaginally. Only persistent occipitoposterior positions with arrest of descent may require LSCS, but it is not a routine indication.

 

5. Mentoanterior position: Here, the fetal chin is directed anteriorly toward the maternal symphysis pubis. This is the only favorable face presentation in which vaginal delivery is possible, as the head can extend under the pubic arch. Thus, it does not require cesarean delivery.

questions.text: A young female has history of a spontaneous abortion. She has had amenorrhea since then. Her FSH now is 6 mlU/ml. Which of the following can be a cause for her amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Uterine synechiae

 

Uterine synechiae (Asherman’s syndrome)
 

  • It refers to intrauterine adhesions or fibrosis that develop when the endometrium is damaged, most commonly after dilatation and curettage (D&C) following a spontaneous or induced abortion.
  • The endometrium fails to regenerate properly, leading to obliteration of the uterine cavity.
  • As a result, menstrual blood cannot form or exit → secondary amenorrhea occurs.
  • FSH level (6 mIU/mL) is normal, showing that the hypothalamic–pituitary–ovarian axis is intact and functioning normally; the defect is anatomical (uterine), not hormonal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pituitary dysfunction:
 

  • Pituitary lesions (e.g., Sheehan’s syndrome, adenoma) reduce gonadotropin release → low FSH and LH.
  • Here, FSH is normal, hence pituitary dysfunction is excluded.

 

Option B. Ovarian dysfunction:
 

  • In ovarian failure, estrogen production drops → loss of negative feedback → high FSH and LH levels.
  • Since FSH here is normal, ovarian dysfunction is unlikely.

 

Option C. First pregnancy:
 

  • During pregnancy, high estrogen and progesterone levels suppress FSH and LH → very low FSH.
  • This patient has post-abortion amenorrhea, not ongoing pregnancy.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, at 28 weeks gestation comes to the office for follow-up of an abnormal Pap test. The Pap test showed a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immediate colposcopy

 

High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL) on Pap smear indicates a high risk for underlying CIN 2/3 or invasive cervical cancer.

 

  • During pregnancy, the management aims to rule out invasive carcinoma while avoiding harm to the pregnancy.
  • The next best step is colposcopic evaluation with directed biopsy (if needed).
  • Colposcopy is safe in pregnancy, and helps identify whether immediate treatment is necessary or can be deferred until after delivery.
  • Endocervical curettage (ECC) is contraindicated during pregnancy due to risk of miscarriage or preterm labor.

 

Therefore, Immediate colposcopy is the correct next step.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Human papillomavirus (HPV) co-testing:
 

  • HPV testing is used in low-grade lesions or for screening in women ≥30 years, not for HSIL.
  • HSIL already indicates significant abnormality; diagnostic evaluation (colposcopy) is required immediately, not HPV triage.

 

Option C. Loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP):

 

  • LEEP is a therapeutic procedure for confirmed CIN 2/3 or carcinoma in situ.
  • It is not done during pregnancy unless there is strong suspicion of invasive cancer, because it increases risk of preterm labor and pregnancy loss.
  • In this case, we first need to confirm the diagnosis by colposcopy.

 

Option D. Repeat Pap test postpartum:

 

  • This may be done for low-grade lesions (ASC-US, LSIL) found during pregnancy, not for HSIL.
  • Deferring evaluation until postpartum can miss an invasive lesion, which can progress rapidly.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presented with mild pain in lower abdomen. She has had 2 full-term normal deliveries earlier. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks back. On pelvic examination, you find a palpable mass in the adnexa. USG pelvis is shown here. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reassure

 

The ultrasound image shows a thin-walled, unilocular cyst in the ovary measuring about 2 cm, with clear anechoic (black) fluid inside and no solid areas or septations — typical of a functional ovarian (follicular) cyst.

 

  • Follicular cysts develop when a Graafian follicle fails to rupture and continues to enlarge.
  • They are common in reproductive-age women, usually asymptomatic or cause mild pain, and are self-limiting.
  • The size (<3 cm) and simple appearance strongly favor a benign, physiological cyst that resolves spontaneously in 1–2 menstrual cycles.

 

Therefore, the appropriate next step is observation and reassurance.
A repeat ultrasound can be done after 6 weeks if symptoms persist.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hysterectomy + BSO:

 

  • Reserved for postmenopausal women or when malignant features (solid components, septations, papillary projections, ascites) are present.
  • This patient is young, premenopausal, and the cyst is benign-looking — hence, not indicated.

 

Option C. Ovarian drilling:

 

  • Done in polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) as a fertility treatment to induce ovulation.
  • Not relevant here, as this is a single functional cyst, not multiple small peripheral cysts typical of PCOS.

 

Option D. CA-125:

 

  • Tumor marker for epithelial ovarian carcinoma.
  • Has low specificity in premenopausal women (can rise in endometriosis, PID, menstruation).
  • Indicated only if the cyst shows complex or suspicious features — not for a simple, small, anechoic cyst.

choices.text: Exposure to child with a rash
Lack of Rh(D) immunization in prior pregnancy

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman, G2P0A1, at 26 weeks gestation comes to the OPD for an initial prenatal visit. Maternal blood type is O, Rh negative. Indirect Coombs test is negative. Abdominal circumference measures at 34 weeks gestation. USG is shown below. Which of the following factors most likely contributed to this fetal presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Exposure to child with a rash

 

  • The fetus has hydrops on ultrasound (ascites with grossly enlarged abdominal circumference at 26 wks, likely skin/scalp edema ± effusions).
  • Mother is Rh-negative with a negative indirect Coombs, so this is non-immune hydrops.
  • Maternal exposure to a child with a rash suggests parvovirus B19 (erythema infectiosum) → fetal aplastic anemia → high-output cardiac failure → hydrops.
  • This precisely fits the presentation of markedly increased AC and hydrops on USG in mid-pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inadequate maternal folate supplementation:
 

  • Folate deficiency is linked to neural tube defects (anencephaly, spina bifida).
  • NTDs do not cause non-immune hydrops or isolated massive AC increase.
  • Ultrasound would show CNS structural defects rather than ascites/edema.

 

Option C. Lack of Rh(D) immunization in prior pregnancy:
 

  • Would predispose to Rh alloimmunization and immune hydrops.
  • However, this patient’s indirect Coombs is negative, arguing against Rh antibodies.
  • Therefore immune hemolysis is unlikely here.

 

Option D. Nonadherence to vaccination schedule:
 

  • Missing vaccines (e.g., rubella) risk congenital rubella (PDA, cataracts, deafness), not classic hydrops.
  • Rubella is not typically associated with severe fetal anemia leading to hydrops.
  • Does not explain the negative Coombs and hydropic ultrasound picture.

questions.text:
All of the following are causes of this appearance except:

 

 

 

  1. Posterior urethral valve
  2. Esophageal atresia
  3. Anencephaly
  4. Maternal Diabetes
  5. Renal agenesis
  6. PUJO
  7. Duodenal atresia
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 6, 5

 

The ultrasound shows polyhydramnios (large vertical pockets; AFI is markedly elevated in Q2,Q3,Q4).

 

Conditions that reduce fetal urine output (posterior urethral valves, PUJ obstruction) or eliminate kidneys (renal agenesis) cause oligohydramnios—not polyhydramnios—so they are the exceptions.

 

Brief reasoning for each item:

questions.text: What is the next appropriate management in uterine inversion with partially removed placenta?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Manual repositioning of the uterus

 

Uterine inversion is a life-threatening obstetric emergency in which the uterine fundus collapses into or through the cervix, often following placental delivery or excessive cord traction.

 

When the placenta is still attached (fully or partially), attempting to remove it or manipulating the uterus before uterine relaxation can exacerbate hemorrhage and worsen inversion.

 

Stepwise Management:

 

1. Initial stabilization:
 

  • Call for help and start resuscitation (IV fluids, blood if needed).
  • Give oxygen and monitor vitals.

 

2. Uterine relaxation:


Stop oxytocin if ongoing. 

 

3. Repositioning (Johnson’s maneuver):
 

  • Push the inverted fundus upward through the cervix toward the umbilicus using the palm/fingertips.
  • After successful reposition, give uterotonics (oxytocin, methylergometrine) to maintain tone and prevent reinversion.

 

4. Control bleeding:
 

  • If bleeding persists → insert Bakri balloon or perform surgical correction (Huntington/Haultain procedure).

choices.text: Radical vulvectomy with unilateral LN dissection
Radical vulvectomy with bilateral LN dissection

questions.text: A 76-year-old female presented with a non-healing ulcer on the labia majora midline for a period of 6 months, measuring 2 cm x 3 cm. No lymph nodes were palpable. Biopsy shows squamous cell carcinoma. How do you manage this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Radical vulvectomy with bilateral LN dissection

 

The patient is an elderly woman (76 years) presenting with a non-healing vulvar ulcer confirmed as squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) — the most common type of vulvar cancer.

 

The lesion is midline (labia majora midline) and measures 2 × 3 cm.

 

In vulvar carcinoma, the pattern of lymphatic drainage determines the extent of lymph node dissection:

 

  • Lateral lesion (≥1 cm from midline) → drains ipsilateral nodes → unilateral LN dissection.
  • Midline lesion (clitoris, perineum, posterior fourchette, or labia minora/majora midline) → bilateral drainage → bilateral LN dissection is mandatory.

 

Stepwise Management:

 

1. Surgical principle:

 

  • Radical vulvectomy = wide local excision of vulvar lesion + removal of skin, subcutaneous tissue, and deep fascia up to the perineal body.
  • Bilateral inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy = removal of superficial and deep inguinal nodes from both sides.

 

Staging context (FIGO – simplified):

 

 

This case (2×3 cm, midline, no nodes) corresponds to Stage IB → requires radical vulvectomy with bilateral node dissection.

choices.text: Dandy Walker malformation

questions.text: Identify the correct pair of malformations:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dandy Walker malformation

 

 

The ultrasound images show posterior fossa abnormality — a large cystic space posteriorly that communicates with the fourth ventricle, along with elevated tentorium and cerebellar hypoplasia.

 

These are classic features of Dandy–Walker malformation (DWM).

 

Key Sonographic Features of Dandy–Walker Malformation:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acrania: The image shows a fetal ultrasound with a "lemon sign." Typical frontal 'pinching' of calvarium gives a 'lemon' appearance of the skull, This is a tell tale signs of a shallow posterior fossa anomalies or Chiari malformation.

 

Option B. Holoprosencephaly: The image is a fetal ultrasound showing a cystic hygroma, which is a congenital lymphatic malformation. The red arrow points to the fluid-filled sac, which is typically found in the neck or head region of a fetus.

 

Option D. Omphalocele: The image is an ultrasound showing a fetus with gastroschisis.

 

  • In this birth defect, baby's intestines and abdominal organs protrude through a para umbilical outpouching.
  • The exposed organs are not covered by a protective membrane and float in the amniotic fluid, which can cause irritation and swelling. 
  • On the other hand, Omphalocele is a birth defect in which an infant's intestine or other abdominal organs protrude through the umbilicus and are covered by a thin sac.

questions.text: A primigravida came for regular antenatal care in her first trimester. She has no complaints of dysuria or increased frequency, but her urine routine reveals ≥ 10⁵ CFU/ml E. coli. Her urine culture was done again and showed the same organism. What is the most common complication of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans B) Preterm labour

 

The patient has asymptomatic bacteriuria (ASB) in pregnancy — defined as ≥10⁵ CFU/mL of a single uropathogen (commonly E. coli) in two consecutive clean-catch specimens without urinary symptoms.

 

Pathophysiology

 

During pregnancy:
 

  • Progesterone causes smooth muscle relaxation → urinary stasis.
  • Ureteral dilatation + increased bladder volume → predispose to ascending infection.
  • If untreated, ASB can progress to acute pyelonephritis in 20–40% of women.

 

Major Complications:

 

 

Why Preterm Labour is the Most Common Complication

 

  • The infection induces release of inflammatory cytokines and prostaglandins → leads to uterine contractions and cervical ripening.
  • Hence, preterm labour and low birth weight are the most frequent fetal outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Miscarriage: Usually not associated; ASB affects mid-to-late pregnancy rather than early loss.

 

Option C. Fetal hypoxia: Not directly caused; only secondary if severe sepsis occurs.

 

Option D. Chorioamnionitis: Occurs with intra-amniotic infection, usually after rupture of membranes — not with isolated bacteriuria.

questions.text: A 30-year-old nulliparous woman comes to the OPD for evaluation of infertility. The patient has been attempting to conceive for the past 2 years. Menarche was at age 11, and her menstrual cycles occur 2-3 times per year and last 7-10 days. BMI is 35 kg/m². Physical examination shows mild acne and hair growth on the upper lip and chin. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Endometrial carcinoma

 

This patient’s presentation is classic for Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS).

 

Key diagnostic clues:
 

  • Oligomenorrhea / anovulation: Menstrual cycles only 2–3 times per year
  • Hyperandrogenism: Acne, hirsutism (upper lip, chin)
  • Obesity: BMI 35 kg/m²
  • Infertility: Due to chronic anovulation

 

Pathophysiology Link to Endometrial Carcinoma

In PCOS:
 

  • Anovulation → lack of progesterone from corpus luteum
  • Unopposed estrogen exposure → continuous stimulation of endometrial proliferation
  • Leads to endometrial hyperplasia → can progress to endometrial carcinoma (type I, estrogen-dependent).
  • Hence, the greatest long-term risk = Endometrial carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adrenal atrophy: Occurs with exogenous corticosteroid use → not in PCOS.

 

Option B. Cushing syndrome: Can mimic PCOS (hirsutism, obesity), but PCOS itself does not cause Cushing; cortisol levels are normal.

 

Option C. Ovarian carcinoma: Ovaries are enlarged with multiple cysts in PCOS, but the risk of ovarian cancer is not significantly increased; main malignancy risk is endometrial.

 

Summary Table:

questions.text: A 26-year-old P1L1 presents with acute abdominal pain. She has a past history of rheumatic heart disease for which she has undergone mitral valve replacement surgery and is on oral Warfarin. On examination, 14 weeks’ abdominal mass was felt. On USG, 8 x 6 cm unilocular cyst with reticular pattern was observed in left ovary. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Repeat USG after 6-12 weeks

 

Likely diagnosis - Functional (Hemorrhagic) Ovarian Cyst — Conservative Management

 

  • Unilocular cyst with reticular (“lace-like” or “fishnet”) pattern on USG → suggests a hemorrhagic (functional) cyst.
