  • Functional cysts are benign, hormone-related, and usually regress spontaneously within 6–12 weeks. As the patient is on Warfarin (anticoagulant), hemorrhagic cyst formation is common due to bleeding into a functional follicle.
  • Hence, expectant management with repeat USG after 6–12 weeks is the safest approach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Measure CA-125: CA-125 is useful for postmenopausal or suspicious adnexal masses, not for young women with classic benign cystic pattern. In premenopausal women, CA-125 may be falsely elevated due to menstruation, endometriosis, or inflammation. Hence, not the next step here.

 

Option C. Surgical intervention: Indicated only if: Persistent or enlarging cyst, Complex/solid mass, Torsion or rupture, Malignancy suspected

Here, benign pattern + young age + on Warfarin → conservative approach preferred.

 

Option D. MRI pelvis: Used for indeterminate USG findings or complex adnexal lesions when diagnosis is unclear. Here, ultrasound appearance is typical of hemorrhagic cyst, so MRI not required.

 

Summary of Ovarian cyst management:

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. Only one sacral ala is present in Naegele’s pelvis 
  2. Hand prolapse must be managed by LSCS
  3. False labour is rhythmic pain that radiates to thigh and back
  4. Constriction ring is due to injudicious use of oxytocin
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 4

 

Statement 1. Only one sacral ala is present in Naegele’s pelvis: Correct. Naegele’s pelvis = unilateral obliquely contracted pelvis. Caused by arrest of development of one sacral ala (hemisacrum). Results in asymmetrical pelvic inlet — oblique diameter shortened on affected side. Commonly associated with scoliosis and pelvic tilt.

 

Statement 2. Hand prolapse must be managed by LSCS: Correct.

 

  • Hand prolapse: descent of hand alongside the presenting part (usually head). Indicates malpresentation or cephalopelvic disproportion. Vaginal delivery risks cord compression or trauma, hence Caesarean section (LSCS) is the management of choice.

 

Statement 3. False labour is rhythmic pain that radiates to thigh and back: Incorrect.

 

  • False labour (Braxton Hicks contractions): Irregular, non-progressive uterine contractions. Do not radiate to back or thighs. No cervical dilatation or effacement.
  • True labour pain is the one that is rhythmic, increases in intensity, and radiates to the back and thighs → causes cervical changes.

 

Statement 4. Constriction ring is due to injudicious use of oxytocin: Correct.

 

  • Constriction ring (Schröder’s ring): Localized uterine contraction around a fetal part, usually due to hyperstimulation by oxytocics.

questions.text: Which ovarian structure is responsible for the following finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Corpus luteum

 

Corpus luteum — source of progesterone → secretory transformation of endometrium

 

  • After ovulation, the ruptured Graafian follicle transforms into the corpus luteum under the influence of LH. The granulosa lutein cells and theca lutein cells secrete progesterone (and some estrogen). Progesterone acts on the proliferative endometrium (previously estrogen-primed) and converts it into secretory endometrium.

 

Histologic features (as seen in image):

 

  • Tortuous, coiled glands with subnuclear vacuolation (early secretory phase). Edematous stroma rich in glycogen and spiral arterioles. Indicates progesterone activity → hence, corpus luteum is responsible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Secondary follicle: Secretes mainly estrogen, responsible for proliferative phase endometrium (straight glands, dense stroma). Not responsible for secretory changes.

 

Option B. Theca interna: Produces androgens, which are later aromatized to estrogens by granulosa cells. Indirect role in follicular estrogen synthesis, not secretory transformation.

 

Option C. Granulosa cell: In preovulatory follicle, secretes estrogen, leading to proliferation of endometrium. After ovulation, these become granulosa lutein cells, secreting progesterone as part of corpus luteum. So, granulosa cells alone (pre-ovulation) do not cause secretory endometrium.

questions.text: A G3P2L0 presents with 9 weeks of amenorrhea. She has a history of conization being done one year ago and is currently on follow-up, with no recurrence on PAP smear. What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) USG to see cervical length

 

Clinical reasoning: History of cervical conization (removal of part of cervix) can predispose to cervical incompetence (incompetent cervix) → risk of second-trimester pregnancy loss.

 

However, not every woman with a history of conization requires prophylactic cerclage. The first step is assessment of cervical length using transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) at 11–14 weeks.

 

If cervical length <25 mm → consider cerclage.
If normal → continue surveillance; no immediate intervention needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cervical cerclage: Not yet indicated.

 

  • Prophylactic cerclage is done only if: ≥2 second-trimester losses due to cervical incompetence. Short cervix (<25 mm) on TVS before 24 weeks
  • At 9 weeks, evaluation first is required before intervention.

 

Option C. Complete bed rest: Bed rest does not prevent preterm birth or cervical insufficiency. Only supportive in selected cases after intervention.

 

Option D. Abdominal cerclage: Not first-line. Reserved for cases where vaginal cerclage fails or cervix too short/scarred to hold a stitch (usually after failed prior cerclages). Not appropriate as first management step here.

questions.text: At which stage of a woman's life, is the vaginal pH at its maximum?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Postmenopause

 

Normal physiology of vaginal pH:

 

 

Concept:

 

  • Estrogen stimulates vaginal epithelium to produce glycogen, which is metabolized by Lactobacillus (Döderlein’s bacillus) into lactic acid, maintaining a low pH (acidic) environment. In postmenopausal women, estrogen deficiency → loss of glycogen, loss of lactobacilli, and rise in pH → most alkaline vaginal environment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. At puberty: Estrogen starts to rise, but lactobacilli colonization and glycogen deposition are just beginning → pH starts decreasing, not maximum.

 

Option B. Reproductive age: High estrogen → high glycogen → lactobacilli thrive → acidic pH (lowest) to protect against infection.

 

Option C. During pregnancy: Estrogen and progesterone very high → increased glycogen → more lactic acid → very acidic pH, protective against pathogens.

choices.text: Multiparous without previous CS, spontaneous labour
Multiparous without previous CS, induced/CS before labour

questions.text: Modified Robson's classification class 2 includes:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nulliparous, singleton, cephalic, induced labour

 

Modified Robson’s Classification (10-group system) is used by WHO to analyze and compare cesarean section (CS) rates across different obstetric populations.


Each woman admitted for delivery is assigned to one of 10 groups based on 5 obstetric parameters: Parity, Previous CS, Onset of labour, Fetal presentation, and Number of fetuses.

 

Group 1 – 10 (Modified Robson’s Classification):

 

 

Therefore:

 

  • Class 1: Nulliparous + Cephalic + Spontaneous
  • Class 2: Nulliparous + Cephalic + Induced / CS before labour

choices.text: 45mg elemental iron and 400 mcg folic acid twice daily
60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid twice daily

questions.text: A G2P1 woman at 29 weeks POG presents with a Hb of 6.8 g/dl. What is the appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IV iron sucrose

 

Stepwise approach – Management of anemia in pregnancy:

 

 

Reasoning for This Case:

 

  • Patient is 29 weeks (third trimester) → need for rapid correction of anemia before delivery.
  • Hb = 6.8 g/dL → falls into moderate anemia, but not severely symptomatic (no mention of heart failure or hypoxia).
  • IV iron sucrose is preferred because: Safe and effective in 2nd & 3rd trimesters. Rapid rise in Hb and replenishes iron stores. Avoids transfusion risks (reactions, infections, alloimmunization).

 

Therefore → IV Iron Sucrose (Option B. is most appropriate.

 

Iron Sucrose Regimen: Dose calculation:
Required iron (mg) = 2.4 × (Target Hb – Actual Hb) × Pre-pregnancy weight (kg) + 500 mg (for stores)

 

Usually given as 200 mg IV iron sucrose diluted in 100 mL NS, infused over 30 minutes, 2–3 times/week until total dose reached.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood transfusion: 

 

  • Indicated when: Hb <6 g/dL, or Severe anemia with cardiac decompensation, or Need for urgent correction (near term / imminent delivery).
  • Here, Hb is 6.8 g/dL → borderline; IV iron preferred first if stable.

 

Option C. 45 mg elemental iron + folic acid: Too low a dose for therapeutic correction; meant for prophylaxis, not treatment. Used in early antenatal supplementation (for mild anemia or prevention).

 

Option D. 60 mg elemental iron + folic acid: Oral therapy is too slow and poorly absorbed in late pregnancy. Also, may cause GI side effects and poor compliance.

questions.text: For a given drug, animal reproduction studies have shown an adverse effect on the fetus, but there are no adequate and well-controlled studies on humans. However, potential benefits may warrant the use of the drug in pregnant women despite potential risks. Such a drug would be classified as:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Category C

 

FDA Pregnancy Risk Categories 

 

 

The question clearly states:

 

  • Animal studies → adverse effects
  • Human studies → inadequate
  • Possible benefit → may justify use

 

This exactly matches Category C definition. Hence, the correct answer is Category C 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Category B: Incorrect. Animal studies show no harm to fetus, or animal harm not confirmed in humans. 

 

Option C. Category X: Incorrect. Absolute contraindication. Risks outweigh any benefit. In the question, it says “may warrant use despite risk” → not X.

 

Option D. Category D: Incorrect. Confirmed human fetal risk, but may be used in life-threatening conditions (e.g., anticonvulsants). Here, human data not available.

choices.text: Oral fluconazole 150 mg two doses 1 week apart
Metronidazole 200 mg oral TDS for 7 days

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 8 weeks gestation, presents to the outpatient department with complaints of curdy white vaginal discharge, dysuria, and intense itching. Candidal vaginitis is suspected. What will be the best management in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intravaginal topical azole for 7 days

 

Diagnosis: Candidal vaginitis (Vulvovaginal candidiasis)

 

  • Common in pregnancy due to high estrogen levels, increased glycogen deposition, and Candida overgrowth.
  • Typical features: Thick, curdy white discharge. Intense itching and burning. Dysuria and vulval erythema

 

Rationale for Management:

 

Systemic azoles (like oral fluconazole) are contraindicated in pregnancy, especially in the first trimester, because: Fluconazole is teratogenic — associated with congenital anomalies (craniofacial, skeletal defects, cardiac malformations). 

 

Hence, local (intravaginal) antifungal therapy is the treatment of choice.

 

Recommended regimen: Clotrimazole 2% vaginal cream for 7 days or Miconazole / Econazole / Terconazole intravaginally for 7 days

 

These are safe and effective during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral fluconazole 150 mg single dose: Effective in non-pregnant women but contraindicated in pregnancy (teratogenic).

 

Option B. Oral fluconazole 150 mg two doses: Increases exposure → higher teratogenic risk. Absolutely contraindicated in the first trimester.

 

Option C. Metronidazole 200 mg TDS for 7 days: Used for bacterial vaginosis or trichomoniasis, not for Candida infections. Ineffective against fungal pathogens.

choices.text: Perineum, perineal muscles, and >50% of external anal sphincter
Perineum, perineal muscles, and <50% of external anal sphincter
Perineum, perineal muscles, external and internal anal sphincter
Perineum, perineal muscles, anal sphincter complex and anorectal mucosa

questions.text: After the successful delivery of a baby, a grade 3b perineal tear is noticed. Which are the structures injured in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Perineum, perineal muscles, and >50% of external anal sphincter

 

Perineal tears are classified based on the extent of injury to the perineum and anal sphincter complex (as per RCOG classification):

 

Classification of Perineal Tears:

 

 

Subclassification of 3rd Degree Tears:

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, gravida 3 para 2, at 38 weeks gestation comes to the hospital due to contractions. She had a cesarean delivery for breech presentation at 39 weeks gestation in her second pregnancy. Blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg, pulse is 100/min, and respirations are 22/min. Fetal heart rate tracing shows moderate variability, multiple accelerations, and no decelerations. Uterine contractions are regular and occur every 4 minutes. The cervix is 6 cm dilated and 60% effaced, and the fetal vertex is at 0 station. After 2 hours, the patient is suddenly restless and has intense lower abdominal pain. Fetal heart monitoring shows recurrent late decelerations. On pelvic examination, there is moderate vaginal bleeding, the cervix is 6 cm dilated and 60% effaced, and the fetal vertex is at -3 station. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Uterine rupture

 

The patient has a history of a previous cesarean delivery, sudden severe abdominal pain during labor, fetal distress with late decelerations, vaginal bleeding, and loss of fetal station. These are classic signs of uterine rupture, most commonly occurring at the site of a previous cesarean scar.

 

Key features supporting uterine rupture:

 

  • History of prior cesarean scar
  • Sudden, severe abdominal pain during labor
  • Fetal distress (late decelerations)
  • Vaginal bleeding
  • Loss of fetal station (head moves upward)

 

Other Options:


Option A. Fetal nuchal cord: causes variable decelerations, not severe pain or loss of station.


Option B. Normal labor: pain is regular and tolerable, without sudden distress or fetal heart abnormalities.


Option D. Vasa previa: presents with painless vaginal bleeding and fetal bradycardia after membrane rupture, no maternal pain or loss of station.

choices.text: Declare as complete abortion and follow-up in 15 days

questions.text: A patient with 6 weeks amenorrhea and a positive pregnancy test came with complaints of lower abdominal pain, moderate bleeding PV. She was hemodynamically stable. On ultrasound, there was no gestational sac in the uterus. Ovaries were normal and no free fluid in the pouch of Douglas. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Follow-up with beta-HCG

 

This scenario describes a pregnancy of unknown location (PUL) — when a woman has a positive pregnancy test but no evidence of intrauterine or ectopic gestation on transvaginal ultrasound.

 

At this early stage, the situation can evolve into:

 

  • An early intrauterine pregnancy (too small to be seen yet),
  • A completed miscarriage, or
  • A developing ectopic pregnancy.

 

Because of these possibilities, immediate intervention is avoided if the patient is stable. The best next step is to repeat serum beta-hCG testing after 48 hours, along with follow-up ultrasound.

 

How to interpret serial beta-hCG values:

 

  • Normal intrauterine pregnancy: hCG rises by ≥66% in 48 hours.
  • Ectopic pregnancy: hCG rises slower than normal or plateaus.
  • Abortion (failing pregnancy): hCG decreases steadily.

 

Thus, serial hCG helps to safely differentiate between these conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Declare as complete abortion and follow-up in 15 days: In a complete abortion, the hCG levels should already be falling, and ultrasound should show an empty uterus after previously documented intrauterine pregnancy. Here, no previous intrauterine pregnancy was documented, so it could still be an early ectopic pregnancy, which can rupture later if missed. Hence, declaring complete abortion without serial monitoring is unsafe.

 

Option B. Methotrexate injection: Methotrexate is used for confirmed ectopic pregnancy, not for PUL without confirmation. Giving methotrexate now risks terminating a viable intrauterine pregnancy if the pregnancy is simply too early to visualize. It should be considered only when ectopic is proven or strongly suspected (e.g., rising hCG without intrauterine sac once hCG >1500 mIU/mL).

 

Option C. Diagnostic laparoscopy: Indicated only when the patient is unstable (e.g., hypotension, severe pain, internal bleeding) or when imaging and hCG trends are highly suggestive of ruptured or complicated ectopic pregnancy. This patient is hemodynamically stable, with no free fluid in the pouch of Douglas — hence no immediate indication for surgery.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic with complaints of severe pelvic pain, particularly during her menstrual periods, and pain during intercourse for the past several years. On pelvic examination, the gynecologist notes tenderness upon palpation of the posterior vaginal fornix and palpable nodules in the uterosacral ligaments. An ultrasound was performed as shown here. All of the following drugs may be useful except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Estradiol

 

The clinical and imaging findings are typical of endometriosis with bilateral endometriomas (chocolate cysts).

 

Key diagnostic clues:

 

  • Chronic pelvic pain and dysmenorrhea
  • Dyspareunia (pain during intercourse)
  • Nodularity of uterosacral ligaments
  • “Ground-glass” cysts on transvaginal ultrasound → endometriomas

 

Pathophysiology:
 

Endometriosis is an estrogen-dependent disorder in which endometrial tissue grows outside the uterus, causing cyclic bleeding, inflammation, and fibrosis.

 

Estradiol – Exogenous estrogen stimulates growth and proliferation of endometriotic implants. Worsens symptoms and lesion size. Since endometriosis is estrogen-dependent, giving estradiol exacerbates the disease rather than treating it. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medroxyprogesterone acetate: Useful. A progestin that causes decidualization and atrophy of ectopic endometrial tissue. Suppresses LH surge → reduces ovarian steroidogenesis → decreases pain and lesion size. Commonly used for pain relief and hormonal suppression in endometriosis.

 

Option B. Cabergoline: Useful. A dopamine agonist that reduces angiogenesis in endometriotic tissue. Also lowers VEGF (vascular endothelial growth factor) levels. Shown to reduce endometrioma size and pain in some cases.

 

Option D. Letrozole: Useful. An aromatase inhibitor that suppresses estrogen synthesis in both ovaries and endometriotic tissue. Reduces estrogen-driven proliferation and inflammation. Used in refractory endometriosis cases or when combined with progestins.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman who recently delivered a full-term baby presents to the emergency department with complaints of persistent fever, lower abdominal pain, and increasing tenderness over the past few days. She delivered her baby via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery two weeks ago. She has been feeling generally unwell since the delivery, with fatigue and malaise. On examination, the patient appears pale and febrile. Lower abdominal tenderness is noted, particularly on palpation of the uterine fundus. There is also localized redness and warmth over the lower abdomen. Her vital signs reveal an elevated heart rate and temperature. Laboratory tests show an elevated white blood cell count, and imaging studies such as ultrasound and computed tomography (CT) scan reveal thrombosis in the pelvic veins. Which among the following is the next course of treatment for her?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Antibiotics + Heparin

 

This is a case of septic pelvic thrombophlebitis (SPT) — a rare but serious postpartum complication. It typically occurs after delivery (especially within 1–3 weeks) and results from infection and thrombosis of the pelvic veins (usually the ovarian or uterine veins).

 

Pathophysiology:

 

  • During or after delivery, endometrial infection (endometritis) may spread to nearby pelvic veins. The combination of endothelial injury, venous stasis, and hypercoagulability (Virchow’s triad) leads to infected thrombus formation. These septic thrombi may cause persistent fever despite broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • Commonly involves right ovarian vein, as it’s longer and drains directly into the IVC.

 

Clinical Features:

 

  • Persistent spiking fever despite appropriate antibiotic therapy for postpartum endometritis. Lower abdominal or flank pain radiating to groin or upper abdomen. Uterine tenderness or pelvic pain disproportionate to findings. Leukocytosis on labs. CT or MRI shows thrombosis in ovarian or pelvic veins.

 

Management:

 

Mainstay of treatment:

 

  1. Broad-spectrum antibiotics – to cover polymicrobial infection (common organisms: E. coli, Streptococci, anaerobes). Typically Clindamycin + Gentamicin ± Metronidazole, or a single broad-spectrum agent like Piperacillin–Tazobactam.
  2. Anticoagulation with Heparin – to prevent thrombus propagation and promote resolution. Unfractionated or low-molecular-weight heparin is used.

 

Combination of Antibiotics + Heparin leads to dramatic defervescence (drop in fever within 48–72 hours), confirming the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stop antibiotics and start heparin: Incorrect. Infection is a major component of this condition. Heparin alone will not treat the septic focus. Both infection and thrombosis must be addressed simultaneously.

 

Option C. Surgical embolectomy: Reserved only for life-threatening pulmonary embolism not responding to medical management. Rarely indicated in septic pelvic thrombophlebitis, as antibiotics and heparin are usually effective.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy: Not indicated unless there is uncontrolled uterine sepsis or necrosis. SPT is a vascular complication, not confined to the uterus, so hysterectomy does not solve the problem.

questions.text: Which of the following SERMs is approved in senile vaginitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ospemifene

 

Senile (Atrophic) Vaginitis

 

Occurs in postmenopausal women due to estrogen deficiency, leading to: Thinning of the vaginal epithelium. Decreased lubrication. Vaginal dryness, itching, dyspareunia, and recurrent infections

 

Ospemifene is the only SERM approved specifically for the treatment of moderate to severe dyspareunia and vaginal atrophy due to menopause.

 

Mechanism: Acts as a selective estrogen receptor agonist on vaginal and vulvar tissues. Improves vaginal epithelial maturation, increases superficial cell layers, and restores vaginal pH and elasticity. Has anti-estrogenic effects on the breast and neutral effects on the endometrium.

 

Indication: Postmenopausal atrophic vaginitis (senile vaginitis). Administered orally (60 mg once daily)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clomiphene: Acts as an anti-estrogen at the hypothalamus, stimulating ovulation in infertility treatment. No role in atrophic vaginitis.

 

Option C. Tamoxifen: Estrogen antagonist in breast tissue, agonist in endometrium and bone. Used in breast cancer therapy and prevention. Causes endometrial hyperplasia, not suitable for vaginal atrophy.

 

Option D. Raloxifene: Estrogen agonist in bone and lipid metabolism; antagonist in breast and uterus. Used in osteoporosis prevention and treatment in postmenopausal women. No beneficial effect on vaginal epithelium or lubrication.

 

Other treatment Options for Vaginal Atrophy:

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of nausea, increased urinary frequency, and breast tenderness. She has never had a menstrual period. She is actively involved in her school's volleyball team. She is 173 cm tall and weighs 54 kg; BMI is 18 kg/m2. Her breast and pubic hair development are at Tanner stage 5. Which of the following serum assays is the most appropriate next step in the diagnosis of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Human chorionic gonadotropin

 

This patient has primary amenorrhea with fully developed secondary sexual characteristics (Tanner stage 5 breasts and pubic hair). She now presents with symptoms of early pregnancy — nausea, urinary frequency, and breast tenderness.

 

Key diagnostic clue:


A sexually active adolescent girl with amenorrhea and pregnancy symptoms → rule out pregnancy first, regardless of menstrual history.

Hence, the first and most appropriate test is serum or urine β-hCG to confirm or exclude pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Estriol: Estriol is an estrogen measured to assess fetal well-being during pregnancy (e.g., in triple test). Not useful in evaluating amenorrhea or confirming pregnancy.

 

Option B. TSH: Thyroid dysfunction (especially hypothyroidism) can cause menstrual irregularities, but only after pregnancy is ruled out. It is a secondary test, not the first step.

 

Option D. Luteinizing hormone (LH): Measured to evaluate causes of primary amenorrhea like gonadal dysgenesis or hypothalamic dysfunction. However, this patient already shows full sexual maturation and pregnancy-like symptoms, so LH testing is premature until pregnancy is excluded.

questions.text: A 29-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the physician for evaluation of infertility. She has been unable to conceive for 14 months. One year ago, she stopped taking the oral contraceptive pill, which she had been taking since she was 17. Her husband's semen analysis was normal. Four years ago, she had an episode of a pelvic tenderness and vaginal discharge that resolved without treatment. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals. Before her marriage, she was sexually active with 3 male partners and used condoms inconsistently. She is 169 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 86 kg (190 lb); BMI is 31.6 kg/m2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's infertility?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Loss of ciliary action

 

This woman has secondary infertility (previously fertile potential, now unable to conceive) with a normal menstrual cycle, indicating normal ovulation.


The history strongly suggests tubal factor infertility due to prior pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) caused by sexually transmitted infections such as Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Although her infection resolved clinically, it likely caused subclinical tubal damage.

 

Pathophysiology:

 

  • PID leads to inflammation and scarring of the fallopian tubes. Chronic damage destroys tubal cilia, which are responsible for transporting the ovum toward the uterus.
  • Even if tubal patency remains (no complete blockage), loss of ciliary motility prevents fertilization by disrupting gamete transport. The end result is infertility despite normal ovulation and normal semen parameters.

 

Hence, the cause of infertility here is loss of ciliary action within the fallopian tubes secondary to postinfectious damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insulin resistance: Seen in polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), which causes anovulation and irregular menses. This patient has regular cycles, ruling out PCOS as the primary issue.

 

Option C. Ectopic endometrial tissue: Endometriosis can cause infertility but typically presents with pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, or dyspareunia, none of which are reported here. Moreover, her history of pelvic infection and sexual exposure pattern fits PID more closely.

 

Option D. Primary ovarian insufficiency: Presents with amenorrhea or oligomenorrhea and elevated FSH and LH levels. This patient has regular cycles, implying normal ovarian function.

choices.text: 18-year-old with amenorrhea and an elevated prolactin level
16-year-old with amenorrhea with normal secondary sexual characters and no mullerian structures on sonography
16-year-old with amenorrhea with normal secondary sexual characters and uterus seen on imaging

questions.text: In which of the following patients is a karyotype most likely needed?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 16-year-old with amenorrhea with normal secondary sexual characters and no mullerian structures on sonography 

 

In a 16-year-old with primary amenorrhea and normal secondary sexual characteristics but absence of Mullerian structures (uterus, fallopian tubes, and upper two-thirds of the vagina), a karyotype is essential to differentiate between two primary conditions:

 

  1. Mullerian Agenesis (Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser Syndrome - MRKH):
    • Karyotype: 46, XX
    • Normal ovarian function (producing estrogen), leading to the development of secondary sexual characteristics.
    • No uterus or upper vaginal structures due to Mullerian agenesis.
  2. Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS):
    • Karyotype: 46, XY
    • Complete androgen insensitivity results in the inability of the body to respond to androgens.
    • Secondary sexual characteristics develop due to peripheral conversion of testosterone to estrogen.
    • Testes are present (may be intra-abdominal), but Mullerian structures regress due to Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) produced by Sertoli cells.

 

A karyotype test helps differentiate between these conditions, making it essential in this clinical scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 20-year-old with amenorrhea and hirsutism: This is likely PCOS or another hyperandrogenic condition, where karyotyping is not necessary.

 

Option B. 18-year-old with amenorrhea and an elevated prolactin level: This indicates hyperprolactinemia (e.g., due to a prolactinoma or hypothyroidism), where a prolactin assay and imaging, not a karyotype, are the key diagnostic tools.

 

Option D. 16-year-old with amenorrhea, normal secondary sexual characters, and uterus seen on imaging: A functional or structural outflow obstruction (e.g., transverse vaginal septum or imperforate hymen) or constitutional delay of puberty is more likely. Karyotyping is not typically required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A karyotype is necessary to differentiate between Mullerian agenesis (MRKH) and Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS) in a patient with primary amenorrhea, normal secondary sexual characteristics, and absence of Mullerian structures. These conditions have different genetic backgrounds (46,XX for MRKH and 46,XY for AIS), which guides appropriate management.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 1, is seen in the hospital on postoperative day 2 due to lower abdominal pain, chills, and pain with sitting. She came to the hospital when she had no contractions a day after spontaneous rupture of membranes. After a 26-hour induction of labor, she had a primary cesarean delivery for arrest of descent. The breasts are full but have no erythema or fluctuant masses. The uterine fundus is firm and tender to palpation. There is scant serosanguineous drainage from the lower aspect of the incision. Pelvic examination shows a small amount of blood on the perineal pad with mildly foul-smelling discharge. Which of the following is the best regimen for treating this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clindamycin plus gentamicin

 

This patient has postpartum endometritis, a polymicrobial uterine infection that commonly occurs after cesarean delivery, especially following prolonged rupture of membranes and labor induction.

 

Key Clinical Features of Postpartum Endometritis:

 

  • Timing: Usually within 2–10 days after delivery
  • Symptoms: Fever, chills, Lower abdominal or pelvic pain, Uterine tenderness on palpation, Foul-smelling lochia (vaginal discharge)
  • Physical findings: Uterus firm (not boggy, ruling out atony) and tender; incision may show mild drainage but main source is uterine infection.

 

Causative Organisms:

 

  • Polymicrobial infection including:
    • Ureaplasma, Mycoplasma hominis
    • Gardnerellavaginalis
    • Peptostreptococcus, Bacteroides
    • E. coli, Group B Streptococcus

 

Because of this mixed aerobic and anaerobic flora, broad-spectrum coverage is required.

 

Treatment:

 

Empiric antibiotic regimen: Clindamycin + Gentamicin

 

Rationale:

 

  • Clindamycin: Excellent coverage for anaerobes and gram-positive cocci.
  • Gentamicin: Covers gram-negative organisms. This combination provides broad-spectrum coverage against nearly all common postpartum pathogens.

 

Continue IV therapy until the patient is afebrile for ≥24 hours and clinically improved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ceftriaxone: Covers mainly gram-negative and some gram-positive bacteria, but not anaerobes. Inadequate for polymicrobial uterine infection.

 

Option B. Ceftriaxone plus azithromycin: Used for pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis, not postpartum endometritis. Fails to cover the typical postpartum anaerobic flora.

 

Option D. Dicloxacillin: Used for mastitis (Staphylococcus aureus), not uterine infection. No role in postpartum endometritis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine examination. She is a gymnast. Three months ago, she sustained a vulvar contusion during a competition but otherwise she has been healthy. The patient is sexually active with a male partner and uses an intrauterine device for contraception. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Examination shows a mobile, soft, nontender, flesh-coloured, 2-cm cystic mass at the 4 o'clock position at the base of the left labium majus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bartholin duct cyst

 

Bartholin duct cyst is the most likely diagnosis based on:

 

  • Location: 4 o’clock or 8 o’clock position on the posterior aspect of the vaginal introitus (base of labium majus)
  • Character: Soft, mobile, cystic, and usually non-tender unless infected
  • Size: Often 1–4 cm
  • Cause: Obstruction of the Bartholin gland duct, leading to retention of glandular secretions and cyst formation
  • Predisposing factors: Trauma or inflammation (in this case, vulvar contusion could have blocked the duct)

 

Pathophysiology: Bartholin glands (paired glands) are located at 4 and 8 o’clock positions of the vaginal opening. Their ducts open into the vestibule and provide lubrication during sexual activity. Trauma, inflammation, or infection can block the duct → accumulation of mucus → Bartholin duct cyst. If infected, it can form a Bartholin abscess (tender, erythematous, fluctuant swelling).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Condylomata acuminata: Caused by Human Papillomavirus (HPV 6, 11). Appear as multiple, firm, cauliflower-like or verrucous growths, not cystic or fluid-filled. Usually on the vulva, perineum, or anus, not localized to a single cystic lesion.

 

Option C. Gartner duct cyst: Remnant of the Wolffian (mesonephric) duct. Located on the lateral wall of the vagina, not at the labial base. Typically felt as a cyst along the anterolateral vaginal wall, superior to the Bartholin glands.

 

Option D. Hematoma: Occurs acutely after trauma with painful, tender, and often discolored swelling. This patient’s mass is nontender and chronic (3 months), excluding a hematoma.

choices.text: Fractional curettage of the endometrium and endocervix
Dilatation and curettage of the endometrium

questions.text: A 56 year old post-menopausal woman presents with irregular vaginal bleeding for the past 4 months. On transvaginal ultrasound, the endometrial thickness is 2 mm but a focal area shows 6 mm of endometrial thickness. Which of the following is the next best step to diagnose the cause of bleeding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hysteroscopic inspection and selective biopsy

 

In a postmenopausal woman with vaginal bleeding, evaluation aims to rule out endometrial carcinoma or focal intrauterine pathology (like a polyp or submucosal fibroid).

 

On TVS, a uniform endometrial thickness ≤4 mm generally excludes malignancy. However, when there is a focal area of thickening (e.g., localized 6 mm region), it indicates asymmetric pathology, which requires targeted evaluation.

 

Hence, the best diagnostic approach is hysteroscopic inspection with selective biopsy, allowing:

 

  • Direct visualization of the uterine cavity.
  • Precise biopsy of the suspicious area (unlike blind sampling).
  • Diagnosis of focal lesions (e.g., polyps, carcinoma in situ).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fractional curettage: It is a blind procedure; the curette may miss a small focal lesion. Suitable for diffuse endometrial thickening, not focal.

 

Option B. Dilatation and curettage: Also, a blind method and often misses focal pathologies such as polyps or focal hyperplasia.

 

Option C. Hysterectomy: Therapeutic, not diagnostic. Performed only after histological confirmation of malignancy or atypical hyperplasia.

choices.text: 4 contractions in 20 min and 8 contractions in 60 min with changes in cervix

questions.text: All of the following are the diagnostic criteria for preterm labor except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cervix posterior in position

 

Explanation:

 

Preterm labor (PTL) is labor that occurs before the 37th week of gestation. Accurate diagnosis involves evaluating several key criteria:

 

  • Contractions: At least one regular contraction every 10 minutes, or 4 contractions in 20 minutes, or 8 contractions in 60 minutes, with or without pain.
  • Cervical Changes: Cervical dilation greater than 2 cm and more than 80% effacement are significant indicators of preterm labor.

 

The incorrect statement is Option D. A cervix that is posterior in position is not a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor. Instead, the cervix's position may be less relevant than its dilation and effacement in the diagnosis of preterm labor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 4 contractions in 20 min and 8 contractions in 60 min with changes in cervix: Correct. Regular contractions that meet the criteria of 4 in 20 minutes or 8 in 60 minutes, along with changes in the cervix, are used to diagnose preterm labor.

 

Option B. Cervical dilatation > 2 cm: Correct. Cervical dilation greater than 2 cm is a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor.

 

Option C. More than 80 percent effaced cervix: Correct. Cervical effacement greater than 80% is another diagnostic criterion for preterm labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cervix being in a posterior position is not a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor. The diagnosis involves assessing contraction patterns and cervical changes such as dilation and effacement.

 

Ref: Page no 366, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. During the 1st stage of labor, pain is mediated by spinal segments T10 to L1.
  2. The WHO recommends a minimum of 8 antenatal visits to improve pregnancy outcomes. 
  3. Gestational age is calculated from the last day of the last menstrual period (LMP).
  4. Bleeding diathesis is the most common cause of menorrhagia in puberty.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2

 

Statement 1: During the 1st stage of labor, pain is mediated by spinal segments T10 to L1.: In the first stage of labor, pain arises due to uterine contractions and cervical dilatation. The pain is visceral in nature and transmitted via afferent fibers accompanying sympathetic nerves from T10 to L1 spinal segments. In the second stage, pain is somatic, transmitted via pudendal nerve (S2–S4) due to distension of the vagina, pelvic floor, and perineum.

 

Statement 2: The WHO recommends a minimum of 8 antenatal visits to improve pregnancy outcomes.: According to the 2016 WHO Antenatal Care Model, a minimum of 8 antenatal contacts is recommended. This replaced the earlier recommendation of 4 visits under the Focused Antenatal Care (FANC) model. The new model aims to improve maternal and fetal outcomes through more frequent monitoring and counseling.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 3: Gestational age is calculated from the last day of the last menstrual period (LMP).: Gestational age is calculated from the first day of the last menstrual period (LMP), not the last day. Ovulation and fertilization typically occur about 14 days after the first day of LMP. Therefore, gestational age includes roughly two extra weeks before conception.

 

Statement 4: Bleeding diathesis is the most common cause of menorrhagia in puberty.: The most common cause of menorrhagia in puberty is anovulatory cycles due to immature hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis. Bleeding diathesis (e.g., von Willebrand disease) can cause menorrhagia but is not the most common cause — it accounts for around 10–20% of cases in adolescents.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with epithelial ovarian cancer with raised CA-125 and abdominal distension presents with the following CECT. What is the management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chemotherapy followed by debulking

 

Interpretation of the CT: The scan shows diffuse peritoneal deposits and omental caking — characteristic of advanced epithelial ovarian carcinoma. There is also ascites, suggesting peritoneal dissemination.

 

Management principle:

 

  • For advanced ovarian cancer, the two accepted approaches are:
  1. Primary cytoreductive (debulking) surgery followed by adjuvant chemotherapy
  2. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NACT) followed by interval debulking surgery

 

However, when extensive disease is seen on imaging (as here), and optimal debulking (<1 cm residual disease) is unlikely due to diffuse peritoneal spread, neoadjuvant chemotherapy is preferred.

 

Thus:  Initial chemotherapy (usually platinum + taxane-based). Followed by interval debulking surgery after 3 cycles if disease becomes operable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Debulking followed by radiotherapy: Radiotherapy is not part of standard ovarian cancer treatment. Ovarian carcinoma primarily spreads transcoelomically; radiotherapy has a limited role.

 

Option B. Debulking followed by chemotherapy: Primary debulking is done only if disease is resectable. Here, diffuse omental/peritoneal spread indicates unresectable disease initially.

 

Option D. Staging laparotomy: Used for early-stage ovarian cancer to determine extent of spread. Not appropriate in advanced disseminated disease.

 

Management Algorithm:

questions.text: A patient presents at 36 weeks with chronic HTN and 3+ proteinuria. Her BP is 170/100 mmHg and she complains of headache and blurring of vision. What is the best management option?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Labetalol + MgSO4 + Expedite delivery

 

Diagnosis: Chronic hypertension with superimposed preeclampsia — indicated by:

 

  • Known hypertension
  • New onset proteinuria (3+)
  • Severe features: BP ≥160/110 mmHg, headache, visual symptoms.

 

Management Principle:

 

In preeclampsia with severe features, the only definitive treatment is delivery, regardless of gestational age (≥34 weeks).


At 36 weeks, fetal maturity is adequate, so delivery must be expedited.

 

Stepwise Management:

 

  1. Control BP: Labetalol (IV or oral) is first-line antihypertensive in pregnancy. Target: <160/110 mmHg, but maintain uteroplacental perfusion.
  2. Prevent eclampsia: Magnesium sulfate (MgSO₄) is given for seizure prophylaxis. Regimen: Pritchard or Zuspan regimen.
  3. Delivery: Immediate delivery is indicated (either induction or cesarean) after stabilization. No need to delay since fetus is near term (36 weeks).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Labetalol + MgSO₄ + Wait till 37 weeks: Delay in delivery increases risk of eclampsia, placental abruption, and maternal complications.

 

Option C. Labetalol + Corticosteroids + Wait till 37 weeks: Corticosteroids for lung maturity are indicated before 34 weeks, not at 36 weeks. Waiting is unsafe in severe preeclampsia.

 

Option D. Labetalol + Corticosteroids + Expedite delivery: Corticosteroids unnecessary at this gestation; MgSO₄ is required for seizure prophylaxis.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman, gravida 5 para 5, comes to the OPD due to involuntary, intermittent loss of urine over the past 5 months. The patient loses a small amount of urine when asked to cough. She has no dysuria, urgency, or hematuria and usually awakens once a night to void.  Postvoid residual urine volume is 40 mL. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Urethral hypermobility

 

Diagnosis: Stress urinary incontinence (SUI) due to urethral hypermobility.

 

  • Seen in multiparous women with weakened pelvic floor and loss of urethral support.
  • Mechanism: The pelvic floor and endopelvic fascia normally stabilize the proximal urethra. When these supports are weakened, increased intra-abdominal pressure (cough, sneeze, laugh) transiently exceeds urethral closing pressure → leakage of urine.
  • Clinical features: Leakage only with exertion, coughing, or laughing. No urgency or nocturia. Normal postvoid residual volume

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bladder outlet obstruction: Causes hesitancy, weak stream, incomplete emptying, and high residual volume, not intermittent leakage.

 

Option B. Detrusor overactivity: Causes urge incontinence (sudden urge, cannot hold urine). Associated with frequency and nocturia, not stress triggers.

 

Option D. Vesicovaginal fistula: Causes continuous, painless leakage of urine unrelated to activity. Common after pelvic surgery or prolonged labor, not intermittent or exertion-related.

choices.text: A 35-year-old woman who has undergone TAH+BSO
A 9-year-old girl who has Turner syndrome
A 47-year-old woman with hot flushes and history of breast cancer
A 60-year-old woman with a history of ischemic heart disease

questions.text: HRT should be prescribed to which of the following patients?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A 35-year-old woman who has undergone TAH+BSO

 

Rationale: TAH + BSO (Total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy) at age 35 causes surgical menopause with abrupt estrogen withdrawal. This predisposes to severe vasomotor symptoms, osteoporosis, and cardiovascular risks if untreated. Hence, Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) with estrogen alone (since uterus is absent) is indicated until the natural menopausal age (~50 years).

 

Benefits: Relieves hot flushes, night sweats, vaginal dryness. Prevents osteoporosis and premature cardiovascular disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Turner syndrome: Requires pubertal induction with low-dose estrogen, not menopausal HRT. Managed under pediatric endocrinology protocols.

 

Option C. History of breast cancer: Absolute contraindication to systemic estrogen therapy due to risk of recurrence. Use non-hormonal alternatives for symptom control.

 

Option D. Age 60 with ischemic heart disease: HRT should not be initiated after 60 years or in established cardiovascular disease due to increased thromboembolic and cardiac risk.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the menstrual cycle in premenopausal female volunteers with normal ovarian function. Pap smear specimens are taken from each volunteer every 6 days for a month. Microscopic examination of one such specimen shows vaginal epithelial cells with deeply eosinophilic cytoplasm. These types of cells are most likely to be seen in which of the following points in the menstrual cycle?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) B

 

Graph interpretation: The graph shows hormonal fluctuations across the menstrual cycle. Point B corresponds to the late follicular (pre-ovulatory) phase — just before the LH surge and ovulation (around day 12–14). During this phase, estrogen levels are at their peak.

 

Cellular Basis:

 

  • Estrogen dominance during the follicular phase stimulates proliferation and maturation of vaginal squamous epithelial cells.
  • The superficial epithelial cells become large, polygonal, and have small pyknotic nuclei with abundant eosinophilic (acidophilic) cytoplasm — indicating high estrogen exposure.
  • These are referred to as cornified or superficial cells, and they appear most prominently around ovulation (point B).

 

Phase-wise Cytologic Changes:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. D: Incorrect. Corresponds to the early luteal phase, dominated by progesterone. Vaginal cytology shows intermediate cells with basophilic cytoplasm — not eosinophilic.

 

Option C. E: Incorrect. Mid-luteal phase; progesterone peak. Secretory endometrium, intermediate-type cells predominate.

 

Option D. F: Incorrect. End of the cycle, hormonal withdrawal; mixed cell population, not estrogenic pattern.

choices.text: Uterine artery → Arcuate artery → Radial artery → Basilar artery → Spiral artery
Uterine artery → Radial artery → Arcuate artery → Basilar artery → Spiral artery
Uterine artery → Arcuate artery → Basilar artery → Radial artery → Spiral artery
Uterine artery → Basilar artery → Arcuate artery → Radial artery → Spiral artery

questions.text: Arrange the following branches of the uterine artery in the correct sequence as they proceed towards the endometrium:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Uterine artery → Arcuate artery → Radial artery → Basilar artery → Spiral artery

 

The uterine artery is the main arterial supply to the uterus, arising from the internal iliac artery (anterior division). It traverses through the broad ligament and gives off a series of branches that penetrate the myometrium and supply the endometrium.

 

Sequential branching pattern:

 

  1. Uterine artery → runs along the lateral uterine wall within the broad ligament.
  2. Arcuate arteries → run circumferentially within the myometrium.
  3. Radial arteries → branch from arcuate arteries and penetrate the myometrium toward the endometrium.
  4. Basilar arteries → supply the stratum basale (basal layer) of the endometrium.
  5. Spiral arteries → extend into the stratum functionale, the superficial layer that proliferates and sheds during menstruation.

 

 

Physiological importance: Spiral arteries are progesterone-sensitive and play a critical role in endometrial perfusion and implantation. During menstruation, these arteries undergo spasm and breakdown, leading to endometrial shedding. In pregnancy, they undergo trophoblastic remodeling to ensure low-resistance uteroplacental blood flow.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primi is in labor. The baseline FHR is 110 bpm. All are possible causes for fetal bradycardia except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Maternal fever

 

Normal FHR: 110–160 beats per minute.

 

  • FHR <110 bpm for >10 minutes = fetal bradycardia.
  • Bradycardia may be due to maternal, fetal, or drug-related causes that decrease fetal oxygenation or vagal stimulation.

 

Causes of Fetal Bradycardia:

 

1. Maternal causes:

 

  • Hypotension (e.g., after epidural or hemorrhage) → reduced uteroplacental flow
  • Hypothermia → reduced fetal metabolism and heart rate
  • Hypoglycemia → decreased fetal metabolic activity
  • Drugs: Beta-blockers (e.g., labetalol, propranolol) → transplacental effect on fetal heart

 

2. Fetal causes:

 

  • Hypoxia or acidosis (most common cause in labor)
  • Umbilical cord compression or cord prolapse → vagal stimulation
  • Congenital heart block (especially with maternal lupus or Sjögren’s syndrome — anti-Ro/SSA antibodies)

 

Option D (Maternal fever) is Incorrect: Maternal fever causes fetal tachycardia, not bradycardia. The mechanism: increased maternal and fetal metabolism → increased FHR (>160 bpm). Commonly seen with chorioamnionitis or maternal infection.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman is evaluated at her 32nd week of pregnancy. Laboratory results are as follows:

 

Arterial pH: 7.45

PaO2: 110 mm Hg

PaCO2: 30 mm Hg

Bicarbonate: 20 mEq/L

Hemoglobin: 11 g/dL

Blood urea nitrogen:5 mg/dL

Creatinine: 0.6 mg/dL

Which of the following best explains this patient's status?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Normal pregnancy

 

These lab findings represent normal physiological changes in pregnancy.
Let’s interpret each finding:

 

1. Arterial blood gas (ABG) values:

 

  • pH: 7.45 → slightly alkalotic but within normal range
  • PaCO₂: 30 mmHg → low (normal 35–45 mmHg)
  • HCO₃⁻: 20 mEq/L → compensatory decrease
  • Interpretation: Chronic respiratory alkalosis with renal compensation

 

Mechanism: In pregnancy, progesterone stimulates the respiratory center → mild hyperventilation → ↓ PaCO₂ → mild respiratory alkalosis. The kidneys compensate by excreting bicarbonate, maintaining near-normal pH.

 

2. Hemoglobin (11 g/dL): Physiologic hemodilution (physiologic anemia of pregnancy) due to plasma volume expansion > RBC mass increase.

 

3. PaO₂ (110 mmHg): Slightly higher than nonpregnant range (due to hyperventilation and increased alveolar ventilation).

 

4. BUN (5 mg/dL) and Creatinine (0.6 mg/dL): Lowered due to increased renal plasma flow and GFR in pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anemia: Hb is 11 g/dL, which is normal for pregnancy.

 

Option B. Hyperemesis gravidarum: Causes metabolic alkalosis due to vomiting (↑ HCO₃⁻, not ↓).

 

Option D. Preeclampsia: Would show elevated BP, proteinuria, and often elevated creatinine, not low.

choices.text: Prior to the removal of Placenta accreta in Multiparous woman
Patient diagnosed with pedunculated submucous fibroids

questions.text: You would consider uterine artery embolization as a treatment option in all of the following cases except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Patient diagnosed with pedunculated submucous fibroids

 

Uterine artery embolization (UAE) is a minimally invasive interventional radiology procedure that involves occlusion of uterine arteries using embolic agents to reduce blood flow to the uterus or fibroid.

 

Indications:

 

  1. Postpartum hemorrhage (PPH): Life-saving when medical management (uterotonics) fails. Controls bleeding while preserving the uterus.
  2. Placenta accreta: UAE may be done prophylactically before surgical removal to minimize intraoperative bleeding.
  3. Symptomatic uterine fibroids: For women with menorrhagia, bulk symptoms, or anemia who want to avoid surgery and are not seeking future fertility.

 

Contraindications:

 

  • Pedunculated submucous fibroids (Option C.:
    • These fibroids are attached by a stalk and lie partly within the uterine cavity.
    • UAE is contraindicated because: The stalk’s vascular supply may thrombose and lead to fibroid detachment or expulsion, causing infection or sepsis. Poor response to embolization.
    • Surgical removal (hysteroscopic myomectomy) is the treatment of choice.

 

Other Notes:

 

 

Conclusion:


UAE is effective for diffuse uterine bleeding or intramural fibroids, but contraindicated in pedunculated submucous fibroids due to risk of infection and expulsion.

questions.text: A woman presented to the clinic with heavy, painful menses that have worsened over the past year. On pelvic examination the uterus is enlarged and tender. USG is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenomyosis

 

Adenomyosis is characterized by the presence of endometrial glands and stroma within the myometrium.


This leads to diffuse uterine enlargement, dysmenorrhea, and menorrhagia due to cyclical bleeding within the myometrium.

 

Key Diagnostic Features:

 

Clinical Findings:

 

  • Age group: Typically multiparous women aged 35–50 years.
  • Symptoms:
    • Heavy, prolonged menstrual bleeding (menorrhagia)
    • Painful menstruation (secondary dysmenorrhea)
    • Diffuse uterine tenderness and enlargement (“boggy uterus”)

 

Ultrasound Findings (as in the image):

 

  • Diffuse thickening of the myometrium
  • Heterogeneous echotexture
  • Fan-shaped / “Venetian blind” acoustic shadowing
  • Poorly defined endo-myometrial junction
  • Small myometrial cysts (due to trapped endometrial glands)
  • No well-defined mass, unlike leiomyoma

 

Pathophysiology: Caused by invasion of endometrial tissue into the myometrium through the basal layer of the endometrium. Leads to myometrial hypertrophy and increased uterine size. Estrogen-dependent condition, often coexisting with endometriosis or fibroids.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polyps: Focal endometrial overgrowths. Cause intermenstrual spotting or irregular bleeding, not diffuse uterine tenderness or enlargement. USG shows focal echogenic mass within endometrial cavity, not diffuse myometrial heterogeneity.

 

Option B. Leiomyoma: Benign smooth muscle tumor (fibroid). Uterus is firm, irregular, often non-tender. Ultrasound shows well-defined hypoechoic mass with acoustic shadowing, unlike diffuse pattern in adenomyosis.

 

Option D. Endometrial hyperplasia: Caused by unopposed estrogen stimulation. Presents with irregular or postmenopausal bleeding, not pain. Uterus is normal in size; USG shows uniformly thickened endometrium.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, at 38 weeks gestation, comes to the office for a routine prenatal visit. The patient feels well and reports normal fetal activity. Last week, she had nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea for 24 hours, but she has been able to eat and drink normally for the past several days. For the past 2 days, the patient has had increased clear vaginal discharge with irregular, painful contractions but no vaginal bleeding. Temperature is 99.6°F (37.6°C), blood pressure is 132/86 mm Hg, and pulse is 96/ min. The uterus is nontender and the fundal height is 34 cm. Fetal heart tones are 135/ min. Fetal ultrasound shows a cephalic fetus, measuring at the 50th percentile for gestational age, and an amniotic fluid index of 2 cm (normal: >5 cm). Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's amniotic fluid level?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rupture of membranes

 

Diagnosis:  Rupture of membranes (ROM) resulting in oligohydramnios.

 

Key Reasoning:

 

  • History of clear vaginal fluid leakage → strongly suggests amniotic fluid loss.
  • AFI of 2 cm → diagnostic of oligohydramnios.
  • Uterus smaller than expected (fundal height 34 cm at 38 weeks) → due to loss of amniotic fluid volume.
  • Fetus with normal growth and heart rate → no placental insufficiency or infection.
  • Nontender uterus, afebrile → no chorioamnionitis or abruption.

 

Thus, prelabor rupture of membranes (PROM) is the most likely cause.

 

Pathophysiology: Amniotic fluid is produced mainly by fetal urine and resorbed by fetal swallowing. When membranes rupture, fluid leaks through the cervix and vagina. Leads to decreased AFI (<5 cm) and risk of cord compression or infection.

 

Supporting Clinical Features:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fetal congenital infection: Causes hydrops fetalis, hepatosplenomegaly, or polyhydramnios, not isolated oligohydramnios.

 

Option B. Maternal dehydration: May cause mild, transient oligohydramnios, but would resolve after rehydration. The patient is currently well hydrated and has persistent low AFI with fluid leakage.

 

Option C. Normal gestational age variant: AFI normally decreases slightly late in pregnancy but never to 2 cm. AFI <5 cm is pathologic and requires evaluation for ROM or placental insufficiency.

 

Confirmatory Tests for Rupture of Membranes:

 

  1. Speculum examination: Pooling of clear fluid in posterior fornix.
  2. Nitrazine test: Turns blue (alkaline) due to amniotic fluid pH (~7.0–7.5).
  3. Fern test: Microscopic “fern-like” pattern due to crystallized amniotic fluid.
  4. Ultrasound: Confirms low AFI consistent with fluid loss.

 

Management:

 

  • At term (≥37 weeks): Induce labor to prevent infection.
  • At 34–36 weeks: Consider delivery after assessing fetal lung maturity.
  • At <34 weeks: Conservative management with corticosteroids and antibiotics if no infection.

choices.text: GnRH high, FSH low, Estrogen low
GnRH low, FSH low, Estrogen low
GnRH high, FSH high, Estrogen high
GnRH high, FSH high, Estrogen low

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to an acute episode of heavy menstrual bleeding. The patient has a history of menorrhagia, with monthly cycles lasting 7-10 days and brisk blood flow with the passage of large clots. Pelvic examination reveals an enlarged fibroid uterus, and she is found to have significant anemia due to blood loss. The patient is prescribed continuous leuprolide therapy. After several weeks, which of the following sustained hormonal changes are expected to have occurred as a result of the treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GnRH low, FSH low, Estrogen low

 

Step 1: Diagnosis — Uterine fibroids (leiomyoma)

 

  • Common cause of menorrhagia with clots and uterine enlargement.
  • Estrogen-dependent tumor — shrinks with hypoestrogenic states (e.g., menopause or GnRH analog therapy).

 

Step 2: Mechanism of Leuprolide

 

  • Leuprolide is a GnRH agonist (a synthetic analog of gonadotropin-releasing hormone). Its effect depends on administration pattern:

 

 

Step 3: Phases of Action

 

  1. Initial phase (“flare”): Short-term increase in LH, FSH, and estrogen due to pituitary stimulation.
  2. Sustained phase (after 2–4 weeks): Continuous exposure leads to desensitization and downregulation of GnRH receptors in the anterior pituitary. Result: Suppression of gonadotropins (FSH, LH) → reduced ovarian estrogen production.

 

Step 4: Hormonal Pattern (after several weeks):

 

 

Hence: GnRH low, FSH low, Estrogen low

 

Step 5: Clinical Utility in This Case- Fibroids (leiomyoma): Estrogen promotes growth → suppressing estrogen shrinks fibroids and reduces bleeding. Short-term use (≤6 months) is effective for preoperative correction of anemia and reducing uterine volume. Long-term use causes menopausal side effects (hot flashes, vaginal dryness, bone loss).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GnRH high, FSH low, Estrogen low: GnRH secretion itself is not reduced; rather, its effect is blocked by receptor downregulation. Functionally, pituitary "perceives" low GnRH activity → similar to a low GnRH state.

 

Option C. GnRH high, FSH high, Estrogen high: Represents the initial flare phase, not the sustained effect.

 

Option D. GnRH high, FSH high, Estrogen low: Impossible combination; persistent FSH elevation would maintain estrogen production.

questions.text: Identify the procedure shown:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pomeroy's technique

 

Procedure: The Pomeroy’s technique is the most commonly performed method of female tubal sterilization (tubal ligation). It is typically performed postpartum or as an interval procedure.

 

Steps of Pomeroy’s Technique:

 

  1. A loop (knuckle) of the fallopian tube is lifted up with a Babcock’s forceps.
  2. The base of the loop is ligated using an absorbable suture (usually plain catgut or chromic catgut).
  3. The tubal segment above the ligature is then excised.
  4. The cut ends retract away from each other as the ligature dissolves, minimizing chances of recanalization.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Type of sterilization: Tubal ligation (female sterilization).
  • Site: Ampullary–isthmic junction of the fallopian tube.
  • Material: Absorbable suture (plain catgut).
  • Failure rate: Approximately 1–2 per 1000 procedures (very low).
  • Reversibility: Difficult, but recanalization is sometimes possible if enough tubal length remains.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salpingectomy: Involves complete removal of the fallopian tube, not just ligation and excision of a loop. Done in cases of ectopic pregnancy, hydrosalpinx, or risk reduction for ovarian cancer, not for contraception.

 

Option C. Tubal recanalization: A reconstructive procedure to restore fertility by rejoining previously ligated tubes. Opposite of Pomeroy’s ligation.

 

Option D. Parkland procedure: Also, a tubal ligation method, but differs in technique: 

The tube is doubly ligated and a segment excised without forming a loop.

Two separate ligatures are applied 1–2 cm apart, and the intervening segment is removed. Commonly used during cesarean section.

choices.text: Corticosteroids followed by induction of labor

questions.text: A 23-year primi came to the emergency department at 35 weeks of pregnancy with pedal edema and BP of 140/90 mmHg. The urine dipstick was 2+. Her investigations are listed below. Hb – 9.2g%, RBS – 123, SGOT – 250, SGPT- 300, Creatinine-0.7, platelet: 50000. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Induction of labor

 

Diagnosis:  Severe preeclampsia with features of HELLP syndrome.

Justification:

 

  • BP ≥140/90 mmHg with proteinuria (2+) → Preeclampsia.
  • AST/ALT markedly elevated → Hepatic involvement.
  • Platelet count <100,000/mm³ → Thrombocytopenia.
  • Together, these findings fulfill criteria for HELLP syndrome:
  • Hemolysis
  • Elevated Liver enzymes
  • Low Platelets

 

Stepwise Clinical Reasoning:

 

  1. Gestational age = 35 weeks (near term).
  2. HELLP syndrome = life-threatening complication of preeclampsia.
  3. The only definitive treatment = delivery, regardless of gestational age.
  4. Induction of labor is preferred if: Cervix is favorable. Mother and fetus are stable

 

Therefore: Immediate delivery (induction of labor) is indicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Corticosteroids followed by induction of labor: Steroids for fetal lung maturity are useful <34 weeks. Here, the patient is 35 weeks — lungs are mature enough, and delaying delivery increases maternal risk.

 

Option C. Start Labetalol and immediate LSCS: 

 

  • LSCS (Caesarean section) is indicated only if: There is fetal distress. Unfavorable cervix with urgent need for delivery. Failed induction
  • Here, BP is only mildly elevated, and patient can be induced safely.

 

Option D. Induction at 37 weeks: Waiting is unsafe in HELLP syndrome — it can rapidly progress to DIC, liver rupture, or maternal death. Delivery must be done immediately, not delayed.

choices.text: Try to slip the cords over the fetal head
Clamp the cord, cut it and unwind it from around the fetal neck

questions.text: You are an intern and are conducting delivery of a 24-year G2P1. The head is delivered and undergoes restitution and external rotation. When you attempt to deliver the anterior shoulder, you notice that there are 2 tight loops of cord around the neck. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clamp the cord, cut it and unwind it from around the fetal neck

 

The presence of tight loops of the umbilical cord around the fetal neck (nuchal cord) can pose a risk to the fetus during delivery due to compression of the cord and reduced blood flow. In this case, you have already observed two tight loops around the fetal neck, which may hinder the delivery of the shoulders and risk fetal blood loss if not addressed promptly.

The appropriate and immediate step in this situation is to clamp the cord in two places, cut it, and then unwind it from around the neck to avoid tension on the cord and prevent fetal blood loss. This ensures that the delivery can proceed safely without further complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Try to slip the cords over the fetal head: This approach can be considered for loose loops of cord around the neck, which can often be slipped over the head without much difficulty. However, in this case, the loops are described as tight, and attempting to slip them over could be dangerous or ineffective.

 

Option B. Deliver the anterior shoulder immediately: Attempting to deliver the anterior shoulder without addressing the tight loops of cord could cause excessive tension on the cord, leading to cord rupture or fetal blood loss. This is not recommended.

 

Option D. Immediately call for help: While calling for help in a complicated delivery scenario is always a good step, in this situation, the best immediate action is to clamp, cut, and unwind the cord, as delaying to wait for help could put the fetus at risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the presence of tight loops of the umbilical cord around the fetal neck during delivery, the correct action is to clamp, cut, and unwind the cord to avoid complications such as fetal blood loss or cord snapping. This allows for a safe delivery to proceed.

questions.text: A 34-year-old P2L2 is taking “Chhaya” for contraception. She has been taking it for 9 months. She reports to you that she has missed taking the pill for the last 2 weeks as she had been traveling and forgot to carry the pill with her. How many tablets has she missed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2

 

Chhaya: A centchroman (Ormeloxifene) tablet — a non-hormonal, selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) used for contraception. It is not a daily pill, unlike combined oral contraceptives.

 

Dosing Schedule of “Chhaya”:

 

  • 1 tablet twice weekly for the first 3 months (every 3 days).
  • Then 1 tablet once weekly thereafter for maintenance.

 

Interpretation: The woman is in her 9th month of use → she is on maintenance phase (1 tablet per week). She has missed 2 weeks of doses → 1 tablet per week × 2 weeks = 2 tablets missed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1: Would be correct if she missed only 1 week.

 

Option C. 7 & Option D. 14: Incorrect. because Chhaya is not taken daily; it’s a weekly regimen, not a daily contraceptive pill.

choices.text: Attempt IUD removal by means of an IUD hook or long artery forceps
Continue the exam by twirling a cytologic brush in her endocervical canal

questions.text: Ms. T visits the OPD for a routine check. She has a Copper containing IUD inserted 6 months back and is concerned as she cannot feel the thread. Her LMP was 2 weeks back. On speculum examination you see the picture below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Obtain a trans vaginal ultrasound

 

Clinical situation:

 

  • The patient’s IUD strings are not visible — a missing IUD thread situation.
  • The possible causes include:
  1. Strings curled up in the cervical canal.
  2. Expulsion of IUD.
  3. Pregnancy with IUD in situ.
  4. Perforation with IUD migration into the peritoneal cavity.

 

Stepwise Management Algorithm for Missing IUD Strings:

 

Step 1: Rule out pregnancy

 

  • Obtain urine β-hCG test → if positive, manage as per pregnancy with IUD.

 

Step 2: Transvaginal ultrasound (TVS)

 

  • Most appropriate first investigation for locating the IUD.
  • TVS can confirm whether: IUD is in the uterine cavity (proper position or displaced), Expelled, or Perforated through the uterine wall.

 

Findings and Further Management:

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Obtain a KUB radiograph: Only indicated after TVS fails to visualize the IUD, to locate an extrauterine IUD (e.g., perforation into peritoneal cavity).

 

Option C. Attempt IUD removal with IUD hook or artery forceps: Should not be done blindly — risk of uterine or cervical trauma. Only appropriate after confirming intrauterine location by imaging.

 

Option D. Cytologic brush to locate threads: Gentle brushing may be tried if ultrasound confirms intrauterine IUD, but not before confirming its position. Here, TVS is the safest next step.

questions.text: Which of the following is the mechanism of action of the first drug used in the regimen of medical MTP in first trimester?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Progesterone antagonist

 

Medical abortion regimen (≤9 weeks gestation):

 

  • Step 1: Mifepristone (RU-486) — Progesterone receptor antagonist
  • Step 2: Misoprostol — Prostaglandin E1 analogue (given 24–48 hours later)

 

Mechanism of Mifepristone (First Drug):

 

  • Mifepristone blocks progesterone receptors in the uterus and decidua.
  • Progesterone is essential for maintaining pregnancy — it keeps the endometrium intact and suppresses uterine contractions.
  • By antagonizing progesterone, mifepristone causes:
    • Decidual necrosis
    • Detachment of the gestational sac
    • Cervical softening
    • Increased uterine sensitivity to prostaglandins

 

These effects prepare the uterus for expulsion of products when misoprostol (a prostaglandin analogue) is administered.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cyclooxygenase inhibitor: NSAIDs inhibit prostaglandin synthesis, which would prevent uterine contractions, not induce abortion.

 

Option B. PG analogue: Refers to misoprostol, the second drug in the MTP regimen, not the first. Causes uterine contractions and expulsion.

 

Option C. Oxytocin receptor agonist: Oxytocin acts on uterine smooth muscle but is used for induction or augmentation of labor, not first-trimester abortion.

choices.text: Acyclovir and review after 6 weeks for a repeat test

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman approaches the clinic for HPV testing for cervical cancer screening. The HPV is positive for type 18 HPV. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Colposcopy and biopsy

 

HPV types 16 and 18 are high-risk oncogenic subtypes strongly associated with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) and cervical carcinoma. When a screening test detects high-risk HPV (especially 16 or 18), the next step is to perform a colposcopic evaluation of the cervix. Colposcopy allows visualization of abnormal epithelium using acetic acid and Lugol’s iodine, followed by directed biopsy to confirm the grade of the lesion (CIN I, II, or III). This diagnostic step determines whether treatment such as excision (LLETZ or conization) is required.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LLETZ: Loop Electrosurgical Excision of the Transformation Zone is a therapeutic procedure used after confirmation of high-grade CIN (CIN II/III). It is not the first diagnostic step. Performing it without prior biopsy can lead to unnecessary excision and scarring.

 

Option B. Acyclovir and review after 6 weeks: Acyclovir is an antiviral agent effective against herpes simplex virus, not HPV. Human papillomavirus is a DNA virus that is not responsive to antiviral therapy.

 

Option C. HPV vaccine: The vaccine is prophylactic and prevents future infection with HPV types 6, 11, 16, and 18. It has no therapeutic role once infection has already occurred. Therefore, vaccination at this stage will not help in treating the current infection.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a fibroid uterus develops severe acute pain abdomen at 28 weeks of gestation. There is no history of fever. WBC count is 8000 cells/µl. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Torsion of fibroid

 

Subserosal fibroids can grow on a stalk (pedunculated) and may undergo torsion, particularly during pregnancy when the uterus enlarges and shifts position. Torsion causes sudden, localized, and severe abdominal pain due to ischemia of the fibroid tissue. The absence of fever and normal white blood cell count distinguishes torsion from infective causes. There are no uterine contractions or cervical changes, which rules out preterm labor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Red degeneration of fibroid: Also known as carneous degeneration, it occurs due to venous thrombosis within the fibroid, leading to hemorrhagic infarction. It is common in the second trimester and presents with pain, fever, and leukocytosis. The absence of fever and normal WBC count in this case makes red degeneration unlikely.

 

Option B. Preterm labor: Presents with regular uterine contractions and cervical dilation, which are not described here. The pain in preterm labor is typically colicky and associated with uterine tightening, not localized tenderness over a fibroid.

 

Option D. PID: Pelvic inflammatory disease presents with fever, purulent vaginal discharge, and cervical motion tenderness. It is rare during pregnancy because the cervical mucus plug prevents ascending infection.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the OPD for evaluation of increasing lower abdominal pain. There is a tender, symmetric suprapubic mass to the level of the umbilicus. There is a blue-tinged bulge between the labia. Rectal examination reveals an anterior tender, central mass. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hymenal incision and drainage

 

This is a classical presentation of imperforate hymen with hematocolpos (accumulation of menstrual blood in the vagina) and possibly hematometra (blood in the uterus). The blue bulge at the introitus represents a distended hymen due to retained menstrual blood. The appropriate management is a cruciate (X-shaped) hymenal incision, which allows drainage of the collected blood and relieves the obstruction. This procedure is curative and prevents future complications such as endometriosis or infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Karyotype analysis: Not required in this case because the girl has normal secondary sexual characteristics and normal external genitalia. Karyotyping is reserved for cases of primary amenorrhea with absent secondary sexual characteristics or structural anomalies (like MRKH syndrome).

 

Option B. Diagnostic laparoscopy: Not indicated because the diagnosis is evident clinically. Laparoscopy is used for diagnostic uncertainty or when intra-abdominal causes like ovarian cysts are suspected.

 

Option D. Hysterosalpingogram: A radiologic procedure used to evaluate the uterine cavity and tubal patency in infertility, not for diagnosing outflow tract obstruction in adolescents.

questions.text: A 22-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the OPD for worsening acne on her face and body over the last 6 months. She initially attributed the acne to her diet and has been eating healthier to improve the acne and lose weight. The patient has lost 6.8 kg in the last 3 months, but the acne has not improved. BMI is 42 kg/m2. Coarse hair is noted on the chin and upper lip. Pelvic examination shows an enlarged clitoris but otherwise normal external genitalia. Laboratory results reveal elevated total testosterone and normal dehydroepiandrosterone sulphate. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor

 

Diagnosis: Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor (Androblastoma)
This is a rare ovarian sex cord-stromal tumor that secretes testosterone, leading to rapid-onset virilization.

 

Key Diagnostic Clues:

 

  • Rapid onset (within months) of virilizing features → strongly suggests an androgen-secreting tumor rather than PCOS.
  • Virilization signs: clitoromegaly, deepening of voice, male pattern baldness, and marked hirsutism.
  • Hormonal pattern: ↑ Total testosterone (from ovarian source) Normal DHEA-S (rules out adrenal source)

 

Mechanism:


Sertoli and Leydig cells in the ovary produce excess androgens (testosterone) → virilization and suppression of gonadotropins → anovulation and menstrual irregularity.

 

Next Step in Management:

 

  • Pelvic ultrasound or MRI to locate ovarian mass.
  • Surgical removal (unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy) is curative in most cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 21-hydroxylase deficiency (Congenital adrenal hyperplasia): Typically presents in childhood or adolescence with ambiguous genitalia, menstrual irregularities, and elevated DHEA-S (adrenal source). Onset is long-standing, not rapid as in this case. Here, DHEA-S is normal, excluding adrenal pathology.
